headline: Sacrificing Ethics in the Name of a Higher Stock Price
pros:
If you were hired from AppDynamics, or someone from AppDynamics has decided they like you, then you’re likely going to be successful. 

Stock was nice (until it dropped by $100 and has yet to recover)
cons:
You’ll be working less than the industry average regardless of role. Get an internal promotion? Now you’ll make 2/3 of what an outside hire makes in the same position. 

Benefits are mediocre compared to other tech companies in the same position. Except for Stock. 
Which, hopefully, you can stick out 4 years to see most of without needing to take a sabattical from the lack of work life balance here draining your mental health. 

There was a huge hiring front of leadership from AppDynamics following the appointment of the current CRO. This has created a huge culture issue within the company and the exec team has done nothing to address it. 

Work/Life Balance is a pipe dream peddled by the executive team. Do you have a salary? Expect to work 65 hours a week minimum, even in an individual contributor role. 

Hiring sales people like crazy, without scaling Sales support teams (marketing, Ops, channel, CSM). Support is minimal because everyone else is spread so thin. 

Literal product support sits overseas and garners frequent complaints from customers. 

A surprising amount of dollars seem to go toward the sales enablement team( look at the most recent SKO for reference) but I don’t know a single person who really understands how any of our sales tools work. 

The stock price is God. Every single thing revolves around it, at the expense of culture, common sense, and decision making. Things change constantly with seemingly no explanation. Decisions and tool purchases feel RUSHED simply to appear cutting edge to the market. 

And for the love of God, before giving any more money to people.ai , someone in this company figure out how to make their tool work in the ZS ecosystem if it’s going to be the Bible for tracking sales activities.

headline: Fast paced, but with an emphasis on work/life balance
pros:
Despite the fast pace, ZS really spend a lot of time on wellness and making sure we're all balancing work with the rest of our lives. Usually when you think of start-up culture, you think of long days, nights, and weekends. Being on the support side, and working globally, I have had to take a few off-hours meetings, but I'm consistently told by my management to leave early on a Friday to make up for it, or take a half day.

The management across all orgs are all tuned into this culture as well. The org isn't siloed at all, and everyone is willing to step out of their role and help at any given time. The company feels like one big team all working towards the same goals.
cons: The pace is fast, and the staffing is lean, which is sometimes great, but when you run into issues it can be tough to get people focused on them, as opposed to moving on to the next project. Being lean also means QA teams and documentation teams are often slower than the release schedule, which can present some challenges.

headline: Great company, great collegues
pros:
Zscaler is fast paced with a lot going on all the time. I can only speak for the ZWS division based in the Burlington, MA, office. People are super smart, yet they are generous with their time and willing to help out. The product is compelling and solves real world problems. The code is complex, which for me has been an invitation to learn many new things.
The company is growing fast so everyone is expected to step up and contribute. There are more projects available than manpower to accomplish, there is little danger of running out of things to do.
Management is focused on customers, but realistic about what can be done. Good work/life balance.
cons: If you require a lot of direction and structure, Zscaler is not a great fit. People are given responsibility and expected to run with it.

headline: Great potential.
pros: Strong visionary executive leadership. Great transformational technology and solutions. Strong sales enablement team and world class SE’s.
cons: I don’t think it’s a systemic issue, but there is a fair amount of mid-level (AVP/RVP) to frontline manager (RSD) dysfunction, which leads to trust issues and ultimately micro-managerial behavior. Again, I think / hope what I’m seeing is isolated and not a widespread culture issue. The customer-first core values preached at the top are often lost in translation during the sales process. Often pushing customers to work within our sales process (which is supposed be all about the customer, but it’s really just about us getting a sale) and timelines, not the customers. This can be highly effective for a first sale, but exudes a traditional transactional SaaS selling motion, not a long term strategic partner.

headline: Great Talent, Great Culture, Great Technology
pros:
If you are looking for a company where you can see yourself grow professionally and personally, then Zscaler is the place. The culture and talent is like no where else seen. 
I came from infrastructure, network & security industry for more than a decade. Zscaler has built a disruptive technology which is very hard for anyone to replicate. I would consider Zscaler as the 'Apple', 'Salesforce' or 'Tesla' in the CyberSecurity market place. 
Leadership understands the pain of managing in the infrastructure; and have found a solution which delivers a simplified and uber-secured experience; rather than throwing one more security appliance on to your stack.
Recruitment process was very transparent and tough one to crack. Best I have experienced till date. The Onboarding is taken seriously and it's all for good reasons. 
Company benefits are industry standard; but most importantly they offer an awesome ESPP plan with 2 year rollback lock price.
We are in growth phase, all ideas are welcome and listened to.
cons: Since the company is in growth phase, the stock is very volatile. It was considered as one of the highest ranking growth company in 2021. So the only con I would consider is that the equity value differs a lot. If you don't pay attention to that and focus on building the business case than I suppose rest will all build history.

headline: Real picture
pros:
Compensation and Stocks - US and EMEA
Popular SASE solution
cons:
1. It is more like a "family owned" business rather like a publicly listed company. Most operations are run from a single country in APAC, to minimise costs, enjoy exploiting people due to weak rather no labour laws. Literally, no defined working hours. Leaders flaunt overwork and it is wore as a sign of honour.

Covid has accelerated adoption of SASE technology for companies (both based on need and panic) and this has benefitted Zscaler. The product has been majorly unchanged before and post the outbreak but the market demand has steered things in its favour. 

2. State of core teams within the company:

Sales
Most of the RSMs/SE's/SA's are from larger companies and have brought dearth of valuable knowledge with them. This clearly translates into the work they do. Massive pressure on Sales, and lot of focus on "Value" based selling than against actual needs of a customer. 

Product Management:
Chaotic product ownership. There are no existing product specifications/drafts or documented knowledge of how features operate under the hood. The information resides in someone, who does not want to document it, since it would make them less relevant. Features are released silently, without clear steps and customers are left to fish for themselves, spending countless hours with Support (who're equally clueless behind the curtains). 

Engineering:
Massive gap between PM and Developer functions. Both seem to operate in their own silo. Never have I witnessed these two functions in so much of disagreement for GA features

Services (Support/PS/CS):
State of each team is dependent on the local leadership, no established process for a decade old company, overworked teams, poor work culture - majority of the services staff are based out of a single country in the APAC region, flooded with incompetent managers. They force employees to spend their free time outside of work on working extra, attend trainings while working at 100% capacity. 

HR/People
Coaxing new joiners to write shinny Glassdoor reviews to bestow heaps of praises for the company. Absolutely no engagement with employees, no decent system to even manage leaves !!

headline: Great people, great opportunity. 90 days in and I’m excited and motivated.
pros: The platform is really good. Leadership is strong and it’s a very flat org- everyone wants to help. Training is very good and I really like the people.
cons: None really. The challenge is to find companies that are ready for transformation. Eventually all companies will have to be there, so the potential is really good.  It’s an exciting place to be!

headline: Only one month in, but loving everything I've seen so far!
pros: Arguably, Zscaler is one of the hottest companies in technology right now. Solid products that solve actual customer problems with a solid ROI. Huge TAM and hiring continues at a very rapid pace!
cons: Any potential 'Cons' are all attributed to typical growing pains of any hyper growth company. Expectations are high to succeed in your given role, but clearly laid out. Culture is very positive and the glassdoor ratings reflect that.

Whole team left and still the management is clueless how to manage.
So if you want honest reviews before joining Zscaler approach a TAM or support engineer they will let you know what exactly is happening over there.

headline: MEDDIC Wins
pros:
The smartest, most agile, and tenured leadership team who offer feedback and help you grow outside your comfort zone. 

Near perfect sales methodology and deal qualification (MEDDIC)

Amazing product, but huge learning curve for people not selling into Cyber/Network/Infrastructure prior. 

Amazing resources with field marketing, channel partner managers, tech alliance managers, sales enablement. Everything you could want to help you succeed.

Potential to make life changing amounts of money.
cons:
Not as "rah rah" as other tech companies. Yes there are big dreams company wide, but sales reps tend to stay in their lane and focus on themselves.

You have to be extremely fast paced, organized and methodical. Not much room for error in some of the bigger deals/opportunities and people can feel like they are drowning sometimes.

Deal cycles are long as hell and can wear you down.

headline: Opportunity for personal and professional growth
pros:
Zscaler's vision from day one has been about marrying Zero-Trust security with phenomenal user experience in the process. Historically security and other departments within the enterprise have been at odds with each other. Zscaler is now bridging the gap and it's easy to differentiate once a potential customer gets to the architecture planning stage.

Leadership/management truly enables you with all the tools you need and the onboarding/Bootcamp equips you with all the knowledge you need, even if you aren't from the security world. 

Fantastic colleagues all around. Everyone is willing to help each other and it's a one-team unit mentality amongst SDRs all the way up to VP Level, nobody is unapproachable.
cons: With Zscaler being a high-growth organization, it can sometimes feel like you are being pulled in many directions, especially at the start. Over time you will learn how to adjust and prioritize so it's not really a con, management is always happy to help.

headline: Rocket Company
pros: The way sales is led at Zscaler is really outstanding. The support from your team can really be felt and everyone has two goals; customer success and sales reps success. The better these two performs, the better the outcome is for everyone. Process and functions are built for creating exceptional customer solutions that will solve their challenges and by that to drive the sales reps success to next leve.
cons: As Zscaler is a rocket growth company, there's a lot of ground work to be done to make the success. You need to work hard to get the basics in place, so you can execute on exceptional level. Some times the resources are scarred as the growth continues.

headline: Lacks on employee centric behaviour; but still good.
pros:
Supportive team
Massive workload and clientele
Good technology
cons:
They have some unequal policies between Indian employees and US. Compensation and rewards also differ like this. US stakeholders do not care whether a person is on leave or there is a festival.. they bombard us with work. US employees get to share virtual games and meets, are greeted with better employee centric approach than Indians. The HR do not do much on this part. There was literally no activity done over diwali whereas we kept on receiving notifications for Halloween. The management needs to see this


Also, they do not have a permanent or hybrid approach for WFH. Alot of new employees have joined from various locations and would prefer to have an open policy around this so that we all can literally work in peace post covid.

headline: 100% Money Driven Company
pros: Great compensation + RSU package, decent products, brand recognition, great marketing team
cons: You will not enjoy the culture here if you are not money driven. All the CEO cares about is his stock prices and will do whatever it takes to keep driving it up. Sales culture is lacking, too much control is given to individual reps, who again only care about selling as much as possible. They say they're "scaling" which just means hiring so many people that there isn't enough work to go around, so you're stuck doing busy work for a majority of your day. Very distant leadership, don't expect anyone above your manager to know your name or what you do. Lots of marketing gimmicks I couldn't stand behind. Faced nothing but gaslighting and manipulation when I left.

headline: 90 Days in @ Zscaler
pros: My first quarter at the company l must say has been great! Everyone is friendly, helpful, they try to make you feel welcome, they get involved if they think they can assist you or an effort, and l truly have felt set up for success. I have all of the support, people, training and resources l need to do my job, and if there is something l need that l cannot find l am either pointed in the right direction and/or it is built. Everyone is collaborative & open to feedback. Plus, starting a full time remote job during COVID (particularly as a people manager) is tough, but Zscaler has really done a great job to go fully virtual and stay connected.
cons: Like any fully remote company there are existing pains. People tend to work hard but in a vacuum, which results in silos. This sometimes has created duplicative efforts/work. Communication could be better. Company initiatives and goals beyond revenue targets would be great to understand in depth, as they are not expressed in a way that helps drive individual team goals. Benefits packages are another point of stress. Great job getting diverse candidates, more women in leadership, etc., but in order to attract more women & diversity l think taking a closer look at things like maternity/paternity leave are very important. Particularly for a Bay Area based company this package is not competitive, and what l would call to be lower than standard.

headline: Growing company with lots of growing pains
pros:
- You likely wont find a faster growing tech company (over 2000 employees) with as much promise as Zscaler. The timing of the pandemic has only accelerated the potential for Zscaler.
- Great, dedicated coworkers
- Well known and leading product
- Fast growth opportunities
cons:
After 90 days in the role, management sends out a request that we leave a review which is why many of these reviews look great. Dont get me wrong its a very promising company but taking feedback from people who just got done onboarding leaves a lot to be desired***
-truly frugal business
-So many broken or slow operational processes 
- Benefits are very weak compared to industry peers
- if you dont handle change very very well, this might not be the place for you

headline: Great company, great technology & great team
pros:
Just hit 3 months at Zscaler and it's gone by in the blink of an eye, excellent onboarding and training - real energy for success is instilled. My immediate team, wider sales and account teams have also been the most welcoming and supportive. There is a real team drive to make everyone the best they can be.
The technology is truly market leading and is designed to solve real customer challenges.
cons: No Cons, just be comfortable with a rapid pace with a big expectation on everyone to delivering as part of a high performing team - as such you need to be a team player, ready to learn and trust the process that Zscaler adopts to make yourself and your team successful.

headline: A tremendous company with brilliant people!
pros:
I've worked at Zscaler for just under 4 months and I'm blown away by the product, leadership, market opportunity, and sales process. 
Pros
- Personal Development. The leadership team are obsessed with making you better. 
- Market-leading product. It's a pleasure selling a solution that solves significant business issues. 
- Earning potential. Best in class. Remuneration model designed for you to excel.
- Industry. Cloud-based cyber security is board level necessity for every company.
cons: I've yet to come across any actual "Cons". I will say that it's an extremely professional and efficient environment. You won't be handheld, the expectation is that you'll come in, learn, and then do what you need to do. It's a very collaborative team of high performers. If you're not willing to work hard, be a team player, and trust the process, then it's probably not the right company for you.

headline: Great product, but terrible leadership and management making people very unhappy at work
pros: Very good product. Good salary but difficult quotas so you wont never get your bonus but they have a good RSU’s package to compensate that.
cons:
The obsession with the process and worst with the reporting are making people to be fed up. They are loosing the focus in customers. They dont care about employees for them people in the company are not assets. Anybody can do the job if you follow the process, you report everything all the time the report of the report in the report….and you do not have any value. Worklife balance is impossible and if you try to find it they will “invite you” to leave….any success in your role is not recognize by the management, the merit is that you have follow the process, however, if a deal is not happening then the problem is not the process that is magic! It is yours that you wont apply it well. When you need to step out the process to win a deal, then you are blamed also….they are fundamentalist with the process and do not think that we are people selling to people.

Rules are not clear neither , middle management do not know well the process neither so they are not able to transmit nd engage people with the company. Poor leadership and terrible communication and feedback skills.

Many people are leaving due to this.

headline: Regional Sales Manager
pros: great company to work with but intense
cons: great company to work for but intense and meticulous follow up

headline: Culture Getting Worse with each passing day
pros: It WAS an amazing company to work with but can't say this anymore
cons:
1) Culture "WAS" great -
When I joined Zscaler the culture here was extremely great. The entire focus and attention was on the employee's mental heath which no doubt turned in the favor of the company and everybody pushed their limits happily and willingly. But, that doesn't hold true anymore.

2) Benefits do not percolate to IC-
The Senior level management is great, the company policies are great, the CEO is great. But, the benefits do not percolate to the levels of individual contributors.

3) New Managers are the worst-
The new managers have made the lives worst, they are pushing the team members for everything and themselves have no knowledge to match up to the level of a manager. You can't go to them for any assistance but for they'll keep reminding you about the processes.

4) SFDC is more important than the customer - 
The environment is Zscaler has become such that filling ur sfdc is more important than the customer itself and you could get penalized very severly fir the not maintaining ur sfdc hygiene.

5) Assets leaving the Organization-
It is being seen that the Senior level employee and the assests of the organization who had been working in Zscaler for 7-8 years have started leaving the company 

6) Too much Micromanagement-
The micromanagement part has increased a lottttttttttt, the best part of te orgnization was the freedom to make mistakes and to do your work as you please but, that is slowly fading away

7) P&C team-
The P&C team is also not that proactive and concerned about the mental well being of the employees like before

Summary : To sum things up, Zscaler used to be a great organization to work for but that does not hold true anymore, it has also become like any other money minting organization who doesn't give a damn about the employees

headline: A great place to work
pros:
Positive environment 
Values each employee thoughts 
Good learning 
Latest technology stack used
cons: None I could think of

headline: Strong culture, good discipline, meaningful customer solutions
pros:
Superb people-focused culture. One of the top qualities we seek is empathy, and this shows with the engagement that management of all levels brings to the table. Our founder and CEO sets the tone with his hard work, open communication, and employee focus. He is super effective on customer-facing sales calls.

The sales process is highly valued here - we do it not because it's "the process" but rather because it is proven to bring positive results. It provides guardrails and a common language for Reps, SEs and management to collaborate. You will earn serious cash if you embrace it and work hard.

And the solution set is excellent - like "only one in upper right Magic Quadrant" good. The platform approach we bring to customers is well-received: it solves actual problems they have today, and in many cases hits the trifecta of "reduces costs, improves performance, easier to deploy."
cons: Not sure, I consider that a con, but It's not easy to get hired here. You have to really want it, and you have to demonstrate it effectively.

headline: For Marketing Ops, It is good company for entry level

work environment is good.

Lesser Hike

headline: Sales rep in midwest
pros: Incredible energy, fast-pased software company so should be ready to Ready, Shoot, Aim on some things. Unique architecture from any other in the market. Solid comp plan.
cons: For sales reps there's a bit of education to be prepared to be giving to prospects b/c while we are a 14 year old company, there are still a number of enterprise companies you will call into that don't know about or understand Zscaler. Once they get it, they really get it versus the legacy incumbents your go up against.

headline: Great company!!

headline: Good single product - Sweatshop/Militaristic Mentality
pros: Good product in SWG category, but they pay the analysts a LOT of $$$$ for that rating.
cons: Once deployed, CIOs/CISOs realize it is not the complete offering they were sold. They then must rely on partnering with other cloud security offerings to fill the gaps. Not truly a "cloud offering" as much of their budget goes to building physical data centers to match MSFT footprint. This limits on-demand scalability which ultimately results in latency (not ideal conditions for financial transactions). Management DEFINITELY has favorites, which is not fair to newer employees. Overpriced.

headline: More credit hungry managers, non technical PMs and few doers
pros:
In the hot sase and ztna market with a good brand recognition.
Also entering new frontiers with zcp (though playing catchup with palo alto networks with me too tech)
cons:
Exactly same problem as others have called out. Good product team until recently when wrong leaders from legacy companies were hired who brought their own army of sub par people.

PM managers are busy labeling their subordinates work as their own to get more credit (writing email to ceo without acknowledging those who are doing work) but same people lack depth when technical questions are asked.
There are 2 layers of management and then a functional PM and those are now leaving one by one. Expect more yes men and few doers in future, feel bad for engineering though.

It's toxic and stay away, unless you have godfather who are joining from certain companies (even then introspect and ask yourself if it's worth it)

headline: What a great onboarding experience so far
pros: It's been 90 days since I joined Zscaler, and everything about my onboarding experience was great. The greatness started from the interview process, then using the cutting edge tools and people supporting me to be successful. Competitive pay, amazing platform and vision.
cons: Because they want the best in the industry, the interview process tends to be a bit long and in depth. There are so many demands for the cloud platform, you can spend so much time just working and learning. So need prioritization with work - life balance. Benefits varies by region, but will be compensated since the team grows rapidly.

headline: Best Place to Work

headline: Life changing career opp
pros: Working at Zscaler has changed my life. The financial impact of all of the benefits they provide has far outweighed my expectations. It’s a market leading company and while it’s also the hardest job I’ve ever done, it’s certainly the most rewarding. Work hard. Know your business. If you’re a pro you’ll do well here.
cons: Just like every company scaling to get to $1B+ there’s a lot of operational maturity that will come. You have to know how to find and leverage internal resources to be successful.

headline: Was a great place to work until it all went south
pros: Zscaler technology, products and market fit is amazing. It has established a dominant position and is growing which has paid rich dividends for employees who joined before the ipo.
cons:
Certain teams have grown and continue to grow, it depends which team you are in these days. Trainings and TME was fun until they were handed off on platter to head of sales without even asking training teams and since the departure of chief strategy officer in January, Product team is reduced to set of order takers and product leadership is in shambles.
Advice for anyone joining training, tech docs or PM org, do not join. If you are joining sales or engineering org, that's the place to be.

If possible, I will update/edit this after 6 months, stay tuned.

cons: Because they want the best employees, the interview process tends to be a bit long and in depth. Be prepared for technical interviews well as a panel presentation. They give you the topics to study beforehand, however. No English teacher with a red pen mentality.

headline: Worst salary negotiation
pros: Great organization in the field of SaaS, good growth prospects and worst HR........,..,......
cons:
Had 5 rounds of interview, I had a detailed discussion about my expectations in terms of salary and 
benefits going for a interview process 
But after I been through company took u turn and gave different reasons of not giving the salary I had discussed moreover HR team made the entire negotiation worst and finally I had to drop the offer moreover HR team members are not in sync in terms of communication as different people gave me different salary options...all confusion.

My suggestion to all have clear understanding before going for a interview process as it takes couple of weeks and very extensive...at the end if not work out waste of time( most precious resource of the world)

headline: Do not!!! I repeat do not join Zscaler TAC
pros: 1. Open Communication to management
cons:
Modern-Day Slavery

1. In the name of Learning Path, they will ask you to join training on weekends at 10 AM when you have just finished your shift at 6 AM (Sugar quote: It's voluntarily no one is forcing, it will benefit you). They even quoted that you can settle of personal life once you learn every product.

2. Always short staffing, too much caseload and they want an engineer to do everything, take care of your bin, your team's bin, and whatnot, they expect us to be superhuman.

3. Get ready to put your Mental Health at the back seat, zero work-life balance, only work work work, and your appraisal and promotion based on your extra hours, not on your talent or expertise.

4. They want you to learn every product in one month and assume that you have taken training, you can do wonders without any assistance

5. No proper training plans or onboarding process, they will put you on the floor without role-based training and you will keep pinging everyone to get even small help.

6. You have to spend an extra 1 and a half hours every day before the shift to get trained as you cannot do anything in your shiftime.

7. No details provided on policies, comp off, compensation, leave availability, P&C does not know anything about their People and Culture. Even if you are sick or have an emergency...get ready to join the shift.

Zscaler has tripled in size in the last few years, and though they have had some growing pains, have expanded in a thoughtful and focused way. 

Compensation is good, onboarding is focused, and if you like to work hard you will be extremely happy here! I certainly have been!

headline: Emperor has no clothes!
pros:
Market is ready for the scale, company has the advantage of being first
People are hard working and sincere
Customers love the product
cons:
Strong CEO: Leadership is home-built, and wobbly run mostly by founding CEO, who runs the show, but no one stands up to tell him the view of the world.
Weak Support : Lot of customer traction, but product is not built for troubleshooting, engineers tend to push stuff to support, and support is struggling.
Fragile future : Becoming IKEA, of building products, with top-down dates, will lead to quality, as its more driven to deliver quantity and speed. 
Haven't transitioned from startup to public company yet, carrying bad stuff startup (adhoc) and bad stuff of public (numbers focused) companies. 
Team is burnt-out after covid, but no culture that makes the leadership aware of the costs
Lastly, poor diversity, mostly indian "tribes" and white boys "clubs" duking it out.

Excellent salary packages. Excellent leadership, inspirational and motivating leaders. Best place to work at.

headline: Culture is through the roof
pros:
The culture and caliber of people at this company is world class. The platform and value it delivers to our customers is undeniable, and the market is ready for a disruptive but proven leader like Zscaler. The leadership team hires the best talent (smart, sterling character, collaborative and problem solvers). Everyone is aligned and rowing in the same direction, so we can go even faster together as a team. We also have a lot of fun.

Specific to my organization, the SDRs have high IQ and EQ, are outgoing, very driven and eager to learn and to help their teammates. It's an awesome group to be part of, with a lot of creative individuals that share their ideas/tips and proactively push themselves and their teammates to improve daily. Passion and excitement is evident.

The SDR leadership team is also phenomenal, coming to Zscaler from other high-tech companies. They're great at coaching individuals to maximize strengths, learn key skills, and overcome gaps, and they genuinely enjoy doing it! 

Finally, the company recognizes the value that SDRs bring to Zscaler, both to drive more pipeline and more new logos, but also to serve as the talent bench for our sales teams. The career path is real, as we've promoted 8 SDRs in the last 6 months to both sales and renewals roles. It's well known that the sales team here is second to none and they love mentoring SDRs too (this is very valuable to people early in their careers).
cons: We go very fast, so be ready to bring your best every day! If that's how you operate, then you'll do well and will enjoy the challenge.

headline: Solid technology hindered by a declining culture
pros: Strong technology and core team of engineers. Start-up mentality can be exciting and fast-paced. Being part of a growing organization can provide opportunities if you know how to play the game.
cons: Zero transparency throughout the reporting structure. Expectations to be available 24/7 because that's what leadership did/does. Cut-throat culture where overworking and overextending is expected and rewarded. Raising concerns or giving feedback is frowned upon. Departments and roles are constantly changing at a drastic level, but management won't admit it. Shoestring budget when it comes to providing the tools needed to do your job effectively.

headline: What an amazing place to work - the people, process, and product are truly outstanding
pros: I knew before I started that Zscaler was a special place, and I wish I would have joined them years ago. The product is incredible, our customers rave about it. Every customer I've met has been extremely happy with their service! The people here are the top A players. Finally, there's an actual onboarding process, that while intense, develops the skills necessary to become the best at what you do. Mastering your craft, if you will.
cons: Best kept secret in the security world, need to make sure everyone knows about Zscaler!

headline: Great company with great potential
pros:
The product / solution is evolving very quickly to be the leader in the market.
Excellent for career development: a lot of ressources for continuous learning/training for everyone to improve him/herself everyday in different domains.
Great team, great teamwork.
cons:
Strong focus on sales process, may not be appreciated by some people at the beginning.
For beginners, sometimes you feel there is too much information to absorb.

headline: Strong culture, good discipline, meaningful customer solutions
pros:
Superb people-focused culture. One of the top qualities we seek is empathy, and this shows with the engagement that management of all levels brings to the table. Our founder and CEO sets the tone with his hard work, open communication, and employee focus. He is super effective on customer-facing sales calls. 

The sales process is highly valued here - we do it not because it's "the process" but rather because it is proven to bring positive results. It provides guardrails and a common language for Reps, SEs and management to collaborate. You will earn serious cash if you embrace it and work hard.

And the solution set is excellent - like "only one in upper right Magic Quadrant" good. The platform approach we bring to customers is well-received: it solves actual problems they have today, and in many cases hits the trifecta of "reduces costs, improves performance, easier to deploy."
cons: It's not easy to get hired here. You have to really want it, and you have to demonstrate it effectively.

headline: Great company, great culture
pros: People clearly enjoy working here and don't just see it as another job. They believe in the vision and leadership from Jay and others in Senior Management. As everyone wants to be and enjoys being here, it creates a spectacular culture. There is a lot of flexibility for personal growth.
cons: Company is still relatively small which leads to a certain amount of 'growing pains' but that comes with a company of this size and growth.

headline: A great culture of true learning
pros: I have worked in many different organisations of different sizes, they all had a culture that involved learning, but I have never worked in a company where they culture is so open, friendly and encouraging. Zscaler truly embrace the growth mindset. You are encouraged to learn while doing and learning from your peers. The cross department sharing is excellent and best of all, there is no management by fear. You managers (all the way up) actually cares about you and want you to succeed. And if you make mistakes along the way, that is alright, just make sure to learn from it.
cons: So far I have not found any real downside, other than working from a country where they employee footprint is small, we have no office to meet in. All are working from home, well during Covid this is the truth for everyone, but at some point we will return to a semblance of former routines. And then I will miss an office in which to meet co-workers once in a while.

headline: I have been working at Zscaler full time.
pros: Great company culture, Generous benefits. The best HR department I've ever interacted with. Upper level management is very encouraging of finding the right spot to contribute and very flexible. It is a very welcoming and fun place to work
cons: None! Everyone is supportive, wonderful place to work and explore.

headline: Outstanding company, strong culture, and fast paced
pros: Innovative, fast paced, focused on strong leadership principles, tremendous executive support and tons of energy. This place gets you excited to want to work here. Also embraces diversity and the culture of leadership, openness and collective support emanates from the top down. Very glad and proud to work here
cons: As Zscaler grows, it is making investments to drive more concerted diversity growth and heightened awareness of social justice issues. This too will evolve into a strength.

headline: Purpose, payoff and passion.
pros:
- Free-flowing environment
- No politics, only performance
- No Micromanagement, only leadership
- Great Equity options
- Great Benefits
- Good employee engagement programs (HR is surprisingly good)
- Disruptive and future-looking product roadmap
- Co-operative and collaborative culture- Culture is the highest priority
- Zero bureaucracy (You can call the leadership with no appointment)
- Focus on enablement - your personal growth is ZS' objective
- Market leader- no competitor even comes close
- $100 Billion outlook
- Great management- unlike you have ever experienced anywhere else.
- Great people- only 2% selection rate = great peers!
cons:
-	Equity > Cash (not much of a Con for forward-looking people)
-	Free-flowing environment may not suit people used to constant supervision
-	Strong focus on results negates traditional hierarchy/tenure-based growth
-	Difficult environment for conformists as innovation and creativity are encouraged
-	Strong focus on the ability to adopt change- people set in their ways would find it difficult

headline: Awesome work culture
pros:
1) Approachable Management - The management is extremely helpful and approachable. You can simply slack, mail or hangout any employee in the organization and can be very sure to get a response
2) Amazing Culture - The culture of the organization is free from any politics, back-biting etc and is very open and friendly
3) Streamlined Processes - The processes of the organization are very streamlined and everything is very organized. You have someone for each role and no overlapping of responsibilities
4) Culture of extreme ownership - You're not held accountable for anything that you do wrong alone, if you fail you fail as a team. The organization gives immense importance to team work and ownership.
cons: A little bit hectic schedule at times since the organization is expanding right now and can be extremely overwhelming to the new joiners.

headline: Not worth the headache
pros: The product is fantastic, a clear leader in the industry. Opportunity to meet many leaders within the company at internal events. You are made to feel as a large part of the mission.
cons:
- Most toxic work culture I've experienced. Once they burn you out they will replace you without hesitation. I've seen people join and after 3 months they already feel miserable.
- Micromanagement is the worst I've ever seen, implemented in a derogatory way which strips employees of independence and confidence.
- Work hours are 10-12 hours a day, constant pressure to join and accept meetings outside of working hours with little to no compensation.
- HR looks the other way whenever issues are brought to their attention.
- Marketing not taken seriously across the company, focus is on sales.
- Few career growth opportunities and almost always based on favouritism.

headline: Once in a Lifetime Opportunity
pros:
Best in the industry when it comes to industry disruption and technology. Zscaler has taken off and on exciting road to be the best of the best. There is no other leadership team out there that is both driven for the company's success but also receptive to the fact that all employees are key contributors regardless of what level they are at in the organization. Leaders are approachable and will listen to all thoughts and ideas. 

Zscaler is surrounded with exceptional talent and possesses a culture that can not be beat. Employees become more than just co-workers to each other, even during a pandemic.
cons: With success comes hard work, Zscaler is no exception. Like any growing company there are some challenges that arise, just be prepared. With the hard work comes reward.

headline: Best move in my career
pros:
- Pain in the market is huge, and market is coming towards Zscaler
- Product/market fit is exceptionally strong (massive references, CIOs selling on our behalf, Gartner MQ leader 10x in a row, Microsofts only recommended security partner for O365)
- CEO with the best growth story; from humble beginnings to tech tycoon, Jay is the embodiment of visionary CEO who puts the customer first, always
- CRO who creates momentum and removes friction, launches programs you can click into, and gets every single function in the company lined up to support sales. 
- MEDDIC playbook and process to develop your career to the next stage.
cons:
- Can get overwhelmed by information and "required actions"
- If you are used to selling products rather than a vision/platform, you need to think about how to jump this gap
- Work life balance can be challenging, so you need to dedicate yourself to success and find the rhythm that works for you

headline: Good place for growth, learning, visibility.
pros:
1) As an individual we will be valued, appreciated and respected to the core, if we are able to prove our worth. 
2) Good learning
3) Good growth
4) Great hike and promotion
cons:
1) Work life balance is really hard in IT teams.
2) Pay is good but could have been better. Management takes care of this, so not really an issue.
3) Lack of communication about project go live and changes. Sudden surprises with respect to work which affects the life balance.
4) Attracting amazing talents with experience is missing. Company insists more on hiring freshers and training then which will definitely work only if we have enough people to take care of existing tasks/projects. If we don't have enough people with sufficient BW, then training freshers is an additional burn for small teams.

To join a company like Zscaler at a time like this has been somewhat amazing as I can really see what we do, how we do it & actually the overall positive impact it's having! Keep up the true hard work!

headline: Great set of people to work with !
pros: Lots of exciting stuff to learn but the most important aspect are the people. Very friendly people, down to earth and always supportive and helping each other grow. Eventually this shows in the company's performance and results !

headline: senior software engineer
pros: good culture and work life balance
cons: No able to find one

headline: Best place I've worked!
pros: Zscaler does a great job of finding the right people. Everyone I work with is really smart, works hard, and is willing to help and collaborate. Egos are checked at the door for sure! The technology is exceptional, and there is a LOT to learn, but the resources you need are available. There are no barriers, you can reach out to anyone top to bottom and you will get what you need. Communication is open, honest, and frequent from the executive team, and employees are valued.
cons: When you're new it can be tough to navigate where to go to perform certain tasks, but like I said, everyone is willing to serve as a guide and help out when you get stuck.

headline: A True Industry Visionary
pros: The leadership team and support ecosystem is the best I've ever been a part of in my career. The leaders truly invest in your growth and provide many tools and resources to help you be successful.
cons: There's a few manual processes and reporting platforms that can be difficult sometimes to correlate data, but they are steadily working towards a more streamlined way to gather information.

headline: Great technology and culture
pros: Top notch leadership, customer focused organization
cons: Growing very fast, lots of new employees ramping

headline: Great culture, huge market opportunity!
pros: Solving challenges executives really care about. Strong sales process. Great culture
cons: Customer base growing faster than support can hire & train staff. No PS Delivery team, reliant on partners.

headline: Germany, Central Europe
pros: hypergrowth, great spirit, commitment on all levels, excellent onboarding, true leadership, fun and smart people, tremendous pace, huge focus on the individual and their development, transparent performance culture, no politics, learning every day, diverse culture without prejudices
cons: Current WFH environment can be be very challenging at times, but that goes for most of the companies and has nothing to do with Zscaler. ZS is doing everything to stay close to the people and launched various programs to strengthen employee morale.

headline: Best decision I ever made!
pros: The onboarding process with Zscaler is top-notch. I have worked for companies in the past that focus very little on the on-boarding steps that help with a successful transition; the same cannot be said for Zscaler. The attention that has been given to ensuring that the new staff are well-versed, well-trained and comfortable is outstanding. I love that politics are not a part of the everyday life here at Zscaler; there are no egos, no power struggles, no holier-than-thou mentalities here. The people that I report directly and indirectly to are amazingly helpful and really care about my success here.
cons: So far I have none. I love it here!

headline: My first 90 days at Zscaler
pros: Great on-boarding process. Zscaler knows how to bring on new hires and get them up to speed, even during the COVID-19 pandemic. They got me what I needed (laptop, credentials, etc.) a few days before my official start date which let me hit the 1st day running. Team collaboration platforms are great. Team culture is fantastic. People are open to observations from the 'new guy' as well as dumb questions that inevitably get asked from the 'new guy'. I'm really looking forward to my next 90 days and beyond!
cons: Some areas for improvement could be internal documentation management is confusing and fractured - there's a lot of documentation, but it's everywhere and not clear what is definitive and most up to date. The surge in new hires means there are a lot of new people to the sales process and selling the solution without a complete understanding of either the process or the solution. A lot of hands are required to sell, which is confusing. The sales process is well thought out at the high-level, but at the lower levels, needs more work.

headline: Good but cheap roots
pros:
Great product and lots of growth.
Alot of work where you can make yourself look good.
Great espp and rsu stock grant refreshers
cons:
They do some sneaky stuff with comp packages that should be mentioned before you join.

Rsu’s are only granted 4 times a year so your first vest could be late 3 months.

401k employer match of 2k is dollar for dollar BUT you must be employed on the last day of the year December 31st. No exceptions.

There benefits list makes it sound like the perks are included, what they mean is they offer it with premiums. 

You hear free food once a week? I think they should disclose it as free Indian food once a week. Completely lame if you dont like it.

headline: The Transformation is Happening... It's all about Timing!!!
pros:
- Fantastic product portfolio - 9 Year Leader in Gartner Magic Quadrant
- Winning company culture focused on developing its people
- Surrounded by very talented people with growth mindset
- Significant professional growth opportunities as the company works to more than double in size over the next few years
- Timing, Timing, Timing - Zscaler used to be more bleeding edge cloud security but companies are running to the cloud and adopting Zsclaer on a massive basis.
- Onboarding and Enablement are second to none. This team has the right talent... the right content... to meet the demands of a fast growing company.
cons:
- If you don't like to work hard... this is not the place for you
- Not really a con but... lots of staff growth due to meet market demand... so a number of employees ramping to productivity. Just small growth pains as the company grows but Zscaler has a really good onboarding and enablement team.

headline: Great culture, great product, great team
pros:
I joined the organisation three months ago.

- Very structured & welcoming onboarding process, despite not taking place face to face because of covid
- Amazing colleagues, very experienced and generous with their time
- Collaborative culture, good communcations between teams
- Great productive and good sales process, making it easier to take care of customers once they have signed
- Great managers, very supportive and do not micro-manage.
- Customer Success Management means different things to different companies. At Zscaler, a CSM is responsible for understanding customer needs and representing them internally, helping the customer transform, coordinating internal resources and helping sales find opportunities. It is not a commercial role.
cons: None so far! Don't think "too many reply-all to welcome emails" counts as a true drawback :)

headline: Outstanding Company Culture, Great Leadership, Amazing Solution
pros:
As a new member of the Zscaler Family, I've had the pleasure of working closely with our Sales Strategy Enablement Team for our Virtual Sales Kickoff and Virtual Bootcamp. The team did an amazing job on both events. It's challenging to keep the engagement high in a virtual world, however Zscaler has cracked the code. 

The positive energy from the Leadership Team is contagious. This is a fast paced organization that is disrupting the tech industry and they hire top talent. 

Everyone is willing to lean in and help. Zscaler has created a team atmosphere that makes others want to get in the boat and row with you.

The technology WORKS and our customers are HAPPY. A lot of tech companies have Nascar logo slides but are not truly providing game changing solutions to them. Zscaler is protecting those organizations and enabling their workforce to increase productivity. It's great to hear about all of the new wins and case studies.
cons: No cons at this time. Zscaler has a lot of solutions that are part of our Zero Trust Exchange platform and it takes time to fully understand each one. If you're willing to invest into the sales enablement, you will do well.

headline: 90 days in and I'm happy with the company
pros: Market momentum is strong. Zscaler's technology is high quality with real differentiation from competition. There are plenty of sales tools. Plenty of shareable content. Plenty of event marketing. This company is building a strong foundation as the go-to cloud security company of the fast approaching "future".
cons: There is a bit too much noise from having so many tools and metrics to maintain. I believe the metrics are going to narrow down as leadership learns what really matters. For now, there is a lot to track and some of it is superficial. This is a minor problem when considering the market opportunity a sales person has at Zscaler.

headline: Zscaler at Burlington MA USA
pros: Fast paced environment with loads of opportunities to contribute. The company is big, but doesn't have that big company endless rungs of management feel about it. It also has some nice big company perks in the benefits area. Finally, this is the only company I've ever worked at (in a 25 year career) that provided time for folks to learn the corporate culture. Usually, corporate culture is a bunch of words on marketing materials. Here, it seems baked in and it's a pretty good/open culture

headline: Focused and driven organisation with Great support
pros:
The company vision is very clearly set and acts as a shared driving force for all employees as everyone is a stockholder.
Good managerial team, with the right balance to be flexible and adjust tactic based on feedback but also to drive forward with new initiatives at pace.
Very welcoming, supportive and friendly company - I was hired post COVID so have only worked remotely, I've still felt part of the team.
cons: Some growing pains from not having fulling structured processes in place for all functions, this structure is being built out now however.

headline: “Best Place to Work”
pros:
Good management
Great benefits
Healthy work Environment

headline: Excellent organization with excellent leadership
pros:
1. Best in class technology to work upon.
2. Every day a new challenge , no mundane work.
3. Collaborative team and teammates with excellent skills
4.Leadership with clear vision and obsessed with customer experience.
5.Survey on most of decisions to get nerve of employees, this creates better employee engagement and improves trust on organization.
6.Good compensation and excellent employee welfare schemes.
cons:
1 .Guidelines to work in Covid19 situation and training sessions for the same can be given.
2. Stress and Burnout for WFH is common, people and culture team needs to pitch in here.

headline: GREAT Place to Work
pros:
People working with always a "how can I help"
Management get things done, helps, coaches and is transparent 
Technology innovative and many years ahead and still improves massively
cons: no real cons to work here at zscaler

headline: Great Decision for me!
author_position: Senior Vice President, Global Partners & Alliances
pros: High Energy, Fast Pace, Empowered, Growth, Challenge
cons: It requires 110% of you and we are always changing and growing.

headline: Great company culture, feels like being part of a family
pros:
The best aspect of working for Zscaler is the inspirational leadership that comes down from the senior management, starting from the founder and CEO Jay.
The caliber of the people is amazing: I've been working for service providers and technology vendors for almost 25 years, and the professionalism and skills that I've seen here is second to none.
Other than that, the technology is top notch and the capabilities are unique on the market.
cons: No significant issues identified so far.

headline: Great place to be a seller!
pros: Product, Culture, General competence, Enablement, Resources, Fast Paced
cons: Challenges to meet/exceed on a daily basis, have to be prepared and ready to go every single day

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great management, the team collaboration is good, flexibility and focus on what counts - results
cons: Salary could be better - struggled to think of something

headline: Organization with a lot of growth and opportunity.
pros:
- Thorough onboarding
- Bi-weekly trainings to keep you up to speed on competitors and industry changes
- Hands on CEO 
- Team is extremely accepting and everyone is willing to help
cons: - Put into new hire training a little too early on (week 2).

headline: What makes a company a great place to work?
pros:
Zscaler is a company that has never been more relevant. Its products are industry leading and perfectly meet the challenges companies of all sizes are currently facing. 

The addressable market is huge and growing. Security is a must buy, not a nice to have and there is no better place to be than the number 1 ranked Security company.

The third leg of the stool was our ability to sell the product and differentiate against the cheaper or legacy players who competed on price or their ability to bundle within an ELA. With a new Sales leadership team in place , this has been addressed head on and the sales team is becoming word class. 

The company is also changing rapidly. There are so many new roles being created as we rapidly grow meaning there are plenty of opportunities for career progression. Overall, this feels like a great place to learn and develop, the product is great and the future holds a number of exciting developments.

It is still early days for my Zscaler ride but the signs are positive and I am expecting great things from the company in the future.
cons:
with rapid change comes a number of challenges. We still need for some systems and processes to catch up with the new reality of Zscaler. This will take some time.

The expectations have also never been higher. If you do not want to work in a high performing sales culture that demands a lot from its employees, this may not be the place for you.

headline: Awesome people to work with.
pros: Awesome product with great leadership.
cons: They regularly conduct surveys to improve themselves.

headline: Best in Tri-city
pros:
Work life balance
open culture
learning opportunity
cons: I believe there are none.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Very well prepared Onboarding, responsive leadership, great team over all and good guidance on processes, even for people new to sales
cons: Product development not 100% up to speed with customer demands, still potential for increased performance, but pretty good over all

headline: Agile company with great leaders
pros: Experienced leaders, supportive team, highly-relevant product, above average pay
cons: Variable working hours, differing workloads

headline: Best place to grow & succeed, fantastic leadership, very strong solution to sell
pros:
- leadership has a clear concept for value-based-sales 
- very fast-paced, demanding environment
- clear metrics/KPIs to reach
- coaching given adequately
- no micromanagement
- very competent and fair colleagues, lots of humor
- best-practices sharing established 
- hierarchies comparably flat 
- great solution on the market (Forbes2000 / DAX companies use Zscaler successfully), fun to sell
-  American workplace culture (people do get credit for great work, cudos being given, incentives to reach higher....)
- get pay scheme

I joined in Spring 2020 and I am not regretting it.
cons: due to Covid19, office got closed so only remote get-togethers possible

headline: Company culture sucks
pros: Decent pay, stock is doing well.
cons: The culture in the tech teams suck. The teams are almost pitted against each other and there is a lot of finger pointing and deliberately trying to bring people down . Each Director needs to understand that all the teams work for Zscaler and finding faults is not a competition. Also any new ideas or suggestions are shut down fast.

headline: Great place!
pros: Equity opportunities, fast growth, amazing tech. Still a small company
cons: internal training is rough around the edges.

headline: Amazing opportunity
pros: Despite starting in the midst of COVID-19 and not having met a single colleague yet, Zscaler has been able to make me feel part of a great journey and culture and I feel a strong connection with our purpose - I'm very impressed!
cons: It takes too long to fully understand what's expected from you in terms of KPIs, understand business processes etc.

headline: Zscaler is a great company with a great culture!
pros: Technology we sell is second to none. The market is huge and ripe for disruption. The people are smart, motivated, and a pleasure to work with!
cons: I can't think of any!

headline: Company culture like no other!
pros: Zscaler is a fantastic company. Culture of collaboration, no politics, and simply getting things done! I started amid COVID'19 pandemic, yet given how welcoming the people are, I never felt disconnected. I am extremely happy with my decision to join.
cons: None that I have seen thus far

headline: Really happy to be here!  Great people, great tech!
pros: Some of the smartest people in tech are working here! Solid compensation structure. Leadership seems genuinely focused on their "people first" strategy. Awesome culture!
cons: It's hard starting a new job during a pandemic. I've only met one co-worker face-to-face thus far (as part of the interview process right before everything was locked-down). HR team is being very creative to on-board folks during this time. On the benefits side, the 401(k) match is a little low; would be nice if that were bumped-up to industry norms.

headline: Company to work for but like a mass production as in industries and poor management process
pros: Well established and a company which all like to work for
cons: Poor management efficiency and lot of struggle for the management to implement the successful process and concentrate only on delivery instead of smooth product.

headline: A company where you enjoy your daily work
pros:
Highly skilled and professional staff
Great place to work and to grow professionally
Clear vision and mission
cons: Nothing that I can think of

headline: Rare to find an established and stable company with the excitement and energy of a startup!
pros:
Huge market potential spurred by digital transformation and recent WFH movements
Investing heavily in broadening market reach, through acquisitions and aggressive sales hiring
Well-established and stable company, but culture and energy level feel like an early-stage startup - very hard to find
cons:
Zscaler is still coming to terms with transitioning from a single product company to a multi-product company
While having a start up mentality is great, be aware that certain elements of this could inhibit the ability to scale to $1B company

headline: Fast paced, innovative and talented
pros:
This company exudes talent. Surrounded by colleagues that challenge, but appreciate hard work. You'll also have the opportunity to work closely with the VP/CMO on projects. Collaboration and exposure to many different teams across the globe is very cool too. 

I would highly recommend if you have the opportunity to work with a company in a booming industry.
cons: There are days with long hours, but they also allow flexible schedules (post-covid).

headline: Fantastic company to join!
pros: Familiar environment, you can access all company levels, CEO is a great person worry about employees and also customers which is highly appreciated. Very customer oriented and with a great technology. Huge potential as a company. They have also a good Compensation and benefit package and it is perfect Culture to Find the right work live balance. Work from Home is part of the DNA of the company.
cons: As they are growing fast they need to implement new process to mesure this growth and Make sure The success. Sometimes to adapt to those process and methodology can be tough. However the metholodogy works and at this point of the company it is need it.

headline: Excellent working environment
pros: Zscaler is an exciting company with a clear mission and a clear market need. While this public company is embracing a lot of big enterprise process, it still has a "disruptor" feel as it takes its cloud security message to a market that hasn't necessarily understood a better way of doing enterprise security. headline: Extraordinary Company
pros: Amazing Technology. The secret sauce is in the architecture. Flawlessly engineered. Built for the times! Inspired and Inspiring Leadership and Management. Detailed Communication. Decisions are all data driven. Access to quality tools and automation that improves workforce productivity. Culture appeals to thoughtful, empathetic, and process driven personalities that embrace accountability.
cons: Company is growing fast. Remains to be seen how the back office functions will keep up. The sales process is highly disciplined and might not be for everyone. Working at Zscaler is 'more than just a job', it's an experience. If you're looking for work/life balance, this might not be the best place.

headline: Best place to work
pros: Very good environment, Everyone is so supporting, Too much to learn. Best place to work.
cons: i didn't find any con.

headline: Great Company
pros: Human, focused on workers, focused on customers. Positive breathing

headline: A great place to work
pros: Great people and products. Fast-paced and a market leader.
cons: Work-life balance can be difficult with the startup-like culture of Zscaler.

headline: New Culture of A-Players
pros:
- Unanticipated pandemic surged Zscaler demand and made the technology incredibly relevant and critical to businesses in today's environment. 
- The new culture created and fostered by Dali Rajic (CRO) and his former AppD team is that of a hungry and winning group of A-player talent with something to prove. 
- I've never worked with a team who has the ability to move so fast, so effectively. 
- Not only is the talent high, expectations are high, but the support to get you there is unwavering and abundant. 
- The structure provided to help get you started is established and growing. Very impressive enablement structure.
cons: - A lot of change brings on a fair number of challenges. While all intended to lead us to great things, some are feel less than great while you're still trudging through it.

headline: A true leader in Cloud delivered Security
pros: Excellent leadership team with great vision and flawless execution made this company a true leader in the Cloud delivered security market. I am very fortunate to be part of this company.
cons: I have not seen any cons so far

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Solid leadership, product vision & roadmap. Amazing engineering culture. Awesome Indian food.

headline: Great Hyper-Growth Enterprise Cybersecurity SaaS Company
pros:
- Great executive management team that strives to listen to its employees
- Well positioned to take advantage of the ongoing cloud transformation as companies moves from on-premises infrastructure to the cloud
- Some nice traditions that are still observed, e.g. annual beach day, Holi and other cultural celebrations
- Absence of politics for the most part, but something to monitor as the company expands rapidly
- Excellent upper and middle management in most functional areas
cons:
- Lack of diversity in some departments
- Average to mediocre benefits (401K matching, cellphone stipend, no cafeteria at HQ)
- Lack of visibility and manager focus on career growth pathway
- Sometimes management's message on customer satisfaction and operational excellence can come across as lack of employee empathy especially in light of the challenges created by COVID-19

pros: Very Good Place to work
