cons: Stingy with vacation time, expensive health care plan.

headline: I like my work. I like the technology. I like my manager. It's good here.
pros: Disruptive technologies whose time has come. Good processes and support structures. We're learning from mistakes of the past and we're meeting our goals.
cons: None. I reject calls from recruiters.

headline: All around great place to work at
pros:
-Collaborative environment: Not afraid to go up to most people and ask about deadlines
-Great products: We get great customer feedback that allow us to make our products and documentation better
-Great people: Majority of the people here are nice, helpful, and have a sense of humor
-Free snacks, free Monday breakfast, free Thursday lunch,  employee anniversary celebrations, team off-sites
-Constant improvement
cons: The cons are mostly towards certain people that can be hard to reach when it comes to finishing tasks

headline: Great Company, Product, People and Culture
pros: Great team of people to work within a positive, hardworking yet fun environment.  Everyone seems genuinely engaged, excited about what we are doing, and willing / wanting to help everyone succeed and thrive.
cons: No cons.  Medical coverage can be better.

headline: The Right Architecture at the Right Time
pros:
Zscaler has designed their service from the ground up using a multi-tenant cloud architecture, enabling the service to cost effectively scale higher and add new functionality faster than others who just added appliances into data centers and called it a cloud service.  This architecture has enabled Zscaler to capture more of the market as companies shift their apps to the cloud and want to move their security services between wherever the users are and the resources they are trying to access.

Management believes deeply in the mission and is focused and driven with a high bar for entry and high expectations after you join.  For me, this is a positive.  

The company has been growing very fast in the couple years I have been here, which is both a positive and a strain.
cons:
Growing so fast makes it hard to recruit and train new people while continuing to get the job done. 

Some people haven't progressed beyond the way things worked when Zscaler was a startup.

Zscaler is not the place for people who want to coast.  The pace is intense and the expectations are high across nearly all job functions.

headline: Sales Manager
pros: Dynamic, good technology, easy to deploy and use. New solutions introduced into platform. Hot growth prospects, good execution.
cons: Internal communication from HQ to field is often lacking. Management is too US centric.

headline: Great people, Great Product, Great Work/Life Balance

cons: Better benefits are always desirable.

pros: A big family, everyone there is willing to help you to be successful. a very good working atomsphere
cons: hope to have local office soon

headline: After 3 months, I can confirm that I made the right decision to join Zscaler
pros:
I've been with Zscaler for just over 3 months.  In that time, I feel I have been given all the resources, trust, and autonomy/collaboration I need from my team and leadership to make an impact.  People here work hard, care about one another, and have fun with one another - I’ve seen a few of office pranks in just 3 months!  

Our regular Monday breakfasts and Thursday lunches, and our various planned and impromptu activities (ice cream social, churros & hot chocolate, bbqs, cultural celebrations, etc.) provide an opportunity for us to get to know our fellow employees and encourage cross team communication and collaboration.    

Jay, our CEO, is very transparent, humble, and accessible – not at all an “ivory tower” type CEO.  It’s great to work at a growing tech company in a top technology market and not have to commute to San Francisco.
cons:
Growing pains – running out of space in the San Jose HQ office and will be moving teams over the next several months to a new building a few miles away, so interactions, while we are in two buildings, will be challenging.  

It was a challenge to get used to using the G-suite of office products vs Microsoft (both are available, but G-suite is used more frequently to collaborate).

headline: Excellent company culture
pros:
- great solutions which are really think forward and really needed in a connected cloud world
- marvelous company family feeling - everybody working on the same goal and "down to earth"
cons: - customers who don't know about the great value which the company can bring

headline: Solid technology and market
pros: Fantastic technology, excellent benefits, great people
cons: unrealistic sales goals, over segmentation of territories, long sales cycles, micromanagement of the sales process

headline: Great People, Challenging Work
pros: First and foremost, they respect employees here, and everyone is friendly and helpful. That sounds like a cliche to a large extent, but having worked at numerous places where I might have wished for such cliches, it's nice to actually have it in practise. The best part about the place really is the people - they take great pains to ensure they hire for not only competence but cultural fit as well, and now having helped in that process as well as having been through it, I can see how rigourous they are in applying their standards. The work itself is challenging (and there's plenty of it) but work/life balance is well maintained. Compensation and benefits are comparable with other companies in the geography and vertical, and have even recently improved, at least in the UK. They have, and mean in practise, an open communication policy, and are serious about getting things done for customers to improve and secure their move to the cloud. (I've emailed the CEO freely, received excellent replies, and no one minded, not the least of which was the CEO.)
cons: It's a bit of a learning curve to get your head around the different technologies in play - you will need to read A LOT to get up to speed quickly. Their new hire training is effective, and there are online certifications, but it does feel like drinking from a firehose at the start.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Get opportunities to excel in your field, and to work in other areas as well.
cons: Nothing specific that I know of.

headline: Character Building Experience
pros:
Working at zscaler, like any other org has its pros and cons.

- Great technology
- Smart people to work with
- Plenty of things to do
cons:
- Gender Diversity, especially in the leadership is lacking
- A lot of politics and bureaucracy amidst the upper management that causes a lot of confusion among individual contributors
- High churn rate in the orgs
- The pay could be higher 
- Employees are not empowered to be successful
-  There are some people who work 18 hours a day, and others hardly 2/3. This is overlooked by managers and they are fine as long as the work is done. Very unfair.
- No proper goals/ mbos for employees. having those would help
- More internal politics and less work seems to be the mantra amongst the management

headline: A good company to work for! Grow together with Zscaler
pros: Nice training, Free meals, transport and insurance. Apart from that, nice place to learn as Zscaler uses the best technologies available in the market
cons: Poor hike, poor salary structure, poor growth. Have to go through five rounds of interview and one presentation in order to join Zscaler. Once you have cleared all your interviews, you will come to know that the company is not offering salary as expected or as you discussed with HR prior to appearing for interviews

headline: Building something  great
pros: I've been a Zscaler for almost a year and couldn't be happier with the company culture and direction.  The executives at Zscaler frequently mention transparency and encourage an open dialogue in our public forums, and it actually exists. The company has a mature view and perspective toward telecommuting and this is a major plus for the workers not located at/near a corporate site.  Each week there is a company-wide email announcing another major customer win from the week prior. There is tremendous excitement within the employee population - we share the feeling that we're all part of building something great.  The CEO leads the show here and is truly inspirational and works tirelessly.
cons: I don't have any constructive criticism at this point.

headline: Great product, great people and good vibes
pros: Good work life balance, HR working to fix any shortcomings, open door policy to any senior/C-level, start-up energy but large enterprise professionalism.  Pay is above average. A very well organized small company. Promisimg IPO. CEO is one of the brightest guys I met.
cons: Short comings of a fast growing company: permanently bringing in talented people, but at a slower than needed pace. Not all benefits from corporate giants, but working to close the gap.

headline: Infectious team spirit
pros: I've joined Zscaler earlier this year and am very glad I did. Not only did I believe and can now confirm that there is a high demand for the technology, but the spirit within the team is also something quite unique. I have a lot of respect for my colleagues as they are approachable and in their positions by merit. I've also experienced some very smart approaches to working together, sparking cooperation amongst peers and driving business forward. I feel that management is here to guide employees and not overburden us with unnecessary tasks and meetings, just for the sake of it.
cons: Not everything might be in place from the start. It might be good to have a phone call with IT/HR before the start date to ensure equipment/document transfer is smooth.

headline: Team Lead - Product support
pros: Work culture , High visibility , Opportunity for growth & Great Leadership team.
cons: Compensation and too much of work load.

headline: Working here is like being in an abusive relationship
pros: Excellent technology, differentiated in the space, excellent UI and strong sales leadership.
cons: The company lacks direction and either runs like rush hour traffic or a  multi-car pile up - a pattern that seems to keep repeating itself every year. Leadership is extremely poor and the CEO cannot seem to get out of his own way to allow people to do their job, not to mention trust anyone to create success. Everything is slow to happen here and budget approvals are nearly impossible to get because everything comes down to penny pinching. Pay is low and Zscaler's intention is to low ball everyone as much as possible and deny raises when they are deserved. They also like to hire someone to do one job function or manage one territory then pile on more once they are hired. That person must "prove themselves" until the next evaluation period to secure the title or raise they deserved that previous year. They cannot keep good talent and have seen extremely high turnover. Working at this company is like being in an abusive relationship where you are gaslighted,  slapped around and made to feel like you are not worthy. Many people stay here longer than they want to and cannot wait to leave, just counting the days until they vest.

headline: Awesome company
pros: Management knew what the goal of the company is and works towards it. Employees are valued. It believes in work hard and play hard.
cons: I can Not think of much Cons at this time. But I have heard people say that sometimes getting approval for expenses is difficult because of extreme cost conscious policy.

headline: Regional Sales Manager
pros:
Good technology when it works
New leadership seems to have culture back on track
cons:
Crowded market trying to compete with existing, appliance based security products that customers that may not love what they have, but are wary to move away from.  The devil you know...
Company claims a large number of customers but appears that a percentage of those are actually ex-customers having dropped the service, yet are still counted as customers in the marketing slides.
Customers complain of complicated deployments, outtages too often.  As a Cloud-only company the top priority should be stability and UX.
Sales seems to be a dizzying revolving door, mostly from reps leaving vs being let go.  Most companies are intrigued with the solution, but when it comes time to purchase, most find it too risky to move away from existing solution, or deem it a low priority project.
Micro management, daily updates in Salesforce lead to too much time spent on CRM vs selling.  On more than one occasion temporary change in a forecast has led to an immediate call from the manager, even when the change was temporary.
Product bugs lead to prospects dropping POCs

Amazing managers and always evolving cross-functional work flow. 

Proud of the team !!!

headline: Fun People

headline: Reported for fake reviews - here's the truth
pros: For customers that are able to get it deployed without a ton of issues, the product itself is very solid and robust.  When going through a demo with a customer showing what the solution is capable of, I frequently hear things like “wow!” and “that is awesome!”  Though difficult to deploy (much more on that below) the technology behind Zscaler and the capabilities of the solution is most impressive.
cons:
Customer support is terrible, especially during the initial deployment phase, and returns are through the roof high.  When you close a sale, you then have to hand hold the customer and support through the entire deployment process to keep things in line, and then escalate, escalate, and escalate some more when things get out of hand, which happens on almost every deal (not exaggerating).  Many (though far from all) of our deployment technicians are technically capable, but are very difficult to understand, have terrible communication & customer support skills, take forever to respond to inquiries, etc.  I’ve had multiple customers commenting on their deployment experience saying things like “the entire thing has been a sad comedy of errors” and “it’s getting silly, to put it nicely”.  The return rate is the highest I’ve ever seen at a company.  After you close a sale you’re then sitting on pins and needles hoping it doesn’t come back.  This isn’t so much a knock on our deployment team as it is a commentary on the refusal of leadership (specifically Jay) to adequately staff and train the reps.  Multiple requests have been made that would help resolve this issue which Jay has shot down.  

As if the massive returns were not enough, even if everything we sold stayed sold, the team would still be well below 50% of their number due to a combination of a refusal to invest in marketing and an insistence on setting wildly outlandish quotas.  Executive leadership expressed to Jay, with data supporting their case, what quotas should set at.  Jay stubbornly refused and insisted on quotas that were more than double what was proposed.  On a team of more than a dozen tenured seasoned sales professionals, not one made it even halfway to the number this past fiscal year.  (Again, not exaggerating.) 

These returns have had a very negative impact on our relationship with channel partners.  Word has gotten around at CDW & SHI not to waste time selling Zscaler as there’s a good chance it’ll be returned and you’ll have a customer satisfaction issue on your hands.  There are some things going on at a high level to grow these partnerships, but at the ground level where the rubber hits the road, it’s ugly.

Another true story regarding returns: It has happened more than once where a rep would close a deal, then leave Zscaler or move to another role, and then when the deal got returned, the rep that was then covering the territory when the return came took a hit.  They never got paid for the initial sale, yet got dinged when the return came.  That is not right, yet it has happened more than once.  Add this to the list of other shady & unethical things others have reported in their reviews.

If you happen to work in sales for Zscaler, be very sure to keep track of what you earn and triple check your paychecks.  More than once a reps commission check was wrong.  We would have to call out the error, fight to get it corrected, then they acted like everything was fine all along.

One shining light in all the deployment issues was the director of deployment, who was phenomenal to work with and did the best he could with what little funding and resources he was allotted.  He recently left the company, and I can’t say I blame him.  At least when things went south with a deployment, which they often did, we could count on him.  Not any more.  

He’s far from the first director/executive to leave.  The turnover rate at the executive level is unbelievably high.  The CFO that was supposed to help the company go public recently left.  Several area directors have left.  There’s been a high turnover rate with SE managers, CMOs, VP of sales, VP of sales ops, etc.  So many executives leaving is clearly a telling sign.  Why are they leaving?  The word from many of them has been that Jay is an extremely difficult CEO to work for.  He micromanages everything, sets ridiculous expectations, does not empower you to do what you need to do to be successful and meet said expectations, and is stubborn and arrogant beyond belief.   It’s funny - the “Z” in “Zscaler” stands for “Zenith”.  We’re the “zenith of scalability” and when it comes to web security, we offer a level of scalability that others don’t and can’t.  It’s amazing how Jay can understand the importance of scalability in that sense and yet not understand how his micromanagement style is preventing his company from scaling the way it should.

This mass exodus of executive leadership is not a new thing.  Though I believe the recent/current round is likely the worst the company has seen, it has been the modus operandi to have a major shake-up every couple years.  As some have put it “At Zscaler I’m never at a startup - I’m always at a re-startup.”  Jay burns through one round of leaders and then rather than learn anything just replaces them with another set until he burns through them the same way.  

I’ve noticed a trend here on Glassdoor where after an honest detailed negative review is given, a very generic positive review quickly follows.  It seems that something dishonest is going on here to prevent future candidates from seeing the truth about the organization they are considering joining.  For example, sort the reviews by date and notice how two detailed reviews titled “"This a promising company with significant problems on multiple levels" and “"Difficult place to work" were quickly followed by the very generic "Proud to Be at Zscaler" and "Happy at Zscaler".  If that’s not enough, notice the reviews on December 14, 2016.  Roughly a dozen five-star reviews on the same day?!?!?  Clearly dishonestly and unethically gaming the system, and reported to Glassdoor for such.  

As an interesting aside, whoever it was on the Austin team that wrote “"Proud to Be at Zscaler" is either no longer around or on their way out as they are shutting the Austin office down per Jay’s refusal to invest in mid-market.  The aforementioned former CFO told him that he wants this thing to take off and go public, he has got to invest in mid-market.  The former CTO he hired from GE said on a webcast in front of the whole company that mid-market was the biggest area of opportunity for growth.  Many other leaders in the organization, and throughout the industry, have stated the same thing.  Their response?  Refuse to invest in mid-market and kick that team to the curb.  

If you click on “rating trends” above, you’ll notice things peaked around May/June of 2015 and have been on a steady decline ever since.  This can be attributed to several things, but here’s what I see as driving the rating trends: Leading up to and including the May/June 2015 timeframe, there was a lot of excitement.  A new global VP of sales had recently joined.  A new CFO that was going to help us go public.  A solid CMO that was literally smashing our appliance based competition.  A phenomenal sales director was building out the mid-market team to help the company get a steady stream of smaller deals to get to the predictable/repeatable/sustainable place shareholders want to see.  There was a feeling throughout the organization like “this rocket is about to really take off!”  Then everyone gradually started seeing that it was all for naught as Jay stubbornly refused to take any advice from the new leaders he had hired and would not enable them to do what he hired them to do.  It was all downhill from there.  

When it comes to tech companies, Zscaler will go down as one of the greatest blown opportunities by a founder/CEO in history - an exact “what should’ve been but never was” scenario.  He literally had everything he needed to fulfill the vision and then some.  All he had to do was get out of the way.   The right product, at the right place, at the right time, with the wrong leader.  The blockbuster IPO that was touted for so long was not a pipe dream or empty words.  It truly could’ve and should’ve been that way.  

What I have expressed in this review is far from my own isolated opinion.  Most everything I’ve said is right in line with the general consensus of many if not most Zscaler employees.  Anyone who paints a different picture is most likely either being deceptive or is still drinking the kool aid.  Don’t buy it.

Everything I’ve said here has been said internally a thousand times.

headline: Sales
pros: Good Proxy Product, ABA, DLP are more Marketing hype. In comparison to market leaders lack of innovation.
cons:
Be aware, some of the positive reviews are pushed by management. So, to give you real overview about the "culture", I will tell you a real story. I was once in a panel interview with my line Manager and his Boss as well as some other people (Channel, SE). After the panel interview we all were supposed to give a rating of a candidate. I was giving a top recommendation, and my line Manager as well, but then, my Managers Boss gave a "No recommendation", and when my Line Manager saw this, he immediately changed his rating to "No recommendation", only to be in line with his boss. And thats a perfect example about the "culture" there. If you always agree with your boss, you always laugh at his jokes, you never think on your own, then you will be doing good. If on other hand you are a performer who thinks, you will be punished.
Payment is on low industry average, be also aware about stock options, IPO gets delayed every year. Everyting you agree with them, make sure you put this in writing.

headline: Great Leadership
pros: Wonderful work environment with rockstar leadership!  Management from top down are passionate, respectful and transparent.  Zscaler is a great company at an exciting time with loads of opportunity to make an impact.  It's not for the faint of heart.  If you have what it takes to be the best and want to work among the brightest and most passionate, this is the place to be.  Come join a fantastic group of people who are dedicated to making the internet a safer place and we do it all in the cloud.
cons: can't think of any right now.

headline: Fantastic Company - Never Looked Back...
pros: I joined Zscaler from a competitor in 2014 and it was the best move I could ever have made. It is a great culture to work in and they make you feel part of the 'family'. I'm proud to be part of an evolving company that has a clear vision and the passion for technology.
cons: Benefits are minimal in the UK - this is slowly changing.

headline: Fantastic, game changing technology!
pros: Fantastic, game changing technology. Extremely innovative and a key enabler for network and security transformations and cloud initiatives for businesses of all sizes. A genuinely exciting place to work with excellent people!
cons: It can take time to convince some companies that there is a new way to address security ready for today's digital business. The Zscaler brand has a way to go before it catches some of the traditional rivals' brands, but the gap is closing all the time! Zscaler is growing at an incredible rate to meet demand which brings its own challenges.

headline: The Zscaler family; when we come together, we’re unstoppable.
pros: Great employer, revolutionary technology, exceptional team; the place to be!
cons: None I can think of

headline: Love it ! Love it !
pros:
Culture is amazing - people work there to make a real difference and always go out of their way to assist. 
We had an issue with a customer last week and asked for help from engineering and they worked non stop till the customer was delighted. Not satisfied but delighted. 
Everyone in the company is customer focused. 

Then the platform is great - with apps moving tot he cloud organizations are truly challenged on to secure their internet access/gateways. And what about users that are outside the enterprise. These challenges are solved in a unique and efficient way by Zscaler. 

When customers send you all their internet traffic, you start to wonder who is the service provider - the telco providing the connectivity or Zscaler ...
cons: In the past, lots of customers were brought on board very quickly without having the required teams to support them - how this is being more than addressed.

headline: Vibrant and exciting place to work
pros:
Fast moving
People focused
Fast growing company in sector
Unicorn
Great colleagues
cons: Some processes aren't in place if you consider that a con

headline: Very exciting place to work
pros: Fast growing company with an innovative and modern cloud security platform, which is one of the best solution in the IT industry, and very disruptive.
cons: Still in startup mode in some aspects, then some challenges to overcome. Need to continue some key hirings in the field.

headline: Sales
pros: Great opportunity to join a disruptive vendor whose technology genuinely meets the shift to cloud-only by large enterprise. Client list is exceptional.
cons: The usual growing pains of companies in a growth phase is to be expected. All in, self starter attitude recommended.

headline: I joined Zscaler this year because of two things.
pros:
The People: I am a firm believer that you should surround yourself with people you want to look up to, people who will drive you and people who will inspire you. Zscaler has some extremely talented and very successful team members, this continues to improve as Zscaler have a very rigorous but vital hiring process. I encourage you to experience it for yourself.

The Technology: I am far from an IT Security expert (my role doesn't require it) but when I see people who are, getting so excited about a technology I cannot help but be infected by it. I believe its a case of right place, right time.
cons: As with any company growing at speed both in terms of revenue and employees there will always be teething problems, be it systems, process, product issues but I have seen first hand how dedicated the teams are to building world class and getting the right people in place.

headline: Great Place - Right Time
pros: Zscaler is front-and-centre of a huge opportunity to build something amazing in the Cloud Security space. The technology is fantastic, the market position is perfect and  the quality and commitment of the team are second to none.
cons: Growing pains are a fact of life here. But everything can be fixed by hard work!  If something does need fixing, better be prepared to get on with it.

headline: Pre-IPO company that has managed to still keep the innovation and excitement of a startup”
pros: Every day is different and everything you do makes a difference - it's great to see that your contribution makes the company successful.
cons: Find ways to keep the passion and devotion while keeping a reasonable work/life balance. Work smarter not harder.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great team and a great solution. Very happy to be part of this tream. Would absolutely refer jobs to my friends.
cons: At the moment, i can not say anything negative. Maybe this will cahnge in the future, but not right now. No other kontras.

headline: Great company
pros: approachable management, visionary solution and great atmosphere
cons: still a little DIY in some aspects

headline: Zscaler Fantastic Company
pros: Forward thinking, fast growing dynamic organisation.  Great technology and vision for the future.  Some of the greatest minds work at Zscaler.  You are given opportunity, opportunity to make a difference, opportunity to wear different hats, opportunity to move around within the organisation and opportunity to be successful and be part of a great team.  The management listen to what employees want in terms of benefits and listen to the feedback in the field.
cons: Occasionally lacks speed of execution with marketing.

headline: Great technology but poor work condition
pros:
Great product at the right time.
Great technology/market vision
Fast product development
cons:
Benefits package not competitive
Unachievable quota (non-negotiable)
Turnover
No internal promotion
Employees just wait for IPO

headline: Fantastic..
pros: Fantastic people and made to feel very welcome. Very obvious that the company is going places.
cons: So far so good - none come to mind!

headline: Marketing
pros: Great colleagues who are passionate about our offerings.
cons: Wish everyone knew that we are a World Class leader.

headline: Fantastic technology and culture dramatically improving
pros: Business proposition to customers, Technology, Market presence, UK management team is strong and very experienced, great partners especially in the service provider space.
cons: Brand awareness needs improving still but success is leading to this happening by default e.g. Zscaler is still viewed by most as a cloud Proxy service company when the reality is that Zscaler does much more.

headline: A thrill filled rollercoaster ride
pros: Dynamic, industry leading product, inspirational Leadership, Unicorn, pre-ipo, amazing growth and opportunity. The opportunity to build something amazing and being a big cog in a small machine.
cons: It's a start up, lots of organised chaos and definitely lots of change as we define our processes as we grow. As with any hyper-growth company, it's hard work and not for the faint hearted.

headline: Great Exciting Company
pros: Great leadership, exciting product, happy customers, leading technology - Strong future! The platform has such a powerful message and customers really understand the shift toward cloud.
cons: Minor growing pains as to be expected in a rapidly growing business

headline: Fantastic Company, Great Vision
pros: Great product, and great vision.  Totally transformational network and security play.  Engaging executive team get involved in winning with the team.
cons: Fast pace often comes with long hours.  Selling transformation means working with multiple stakeholders in the customer, which can take time but pays off.

headline: Exciting, Dynamic & Positive Company
pros:
Market leading company that is genuinely changing IT.
Great people who are knowledgeable & passionate.
Can do and will do attitude.
cons: It's a start up so don't expect everything to be in place but then that's the fun by being part of the team that make it happen.

headline: Fantastic company, great technology and a passionate workforce
pros:
Awesome technology, innovative and market leading.

Very flat organisational hierarchy - all of the executive team are approachable and they listen.

Fantastic opportunities for career progression - ideal for self-starters with a can-do attitude.
cons: Depending on your role, the global nature of the organisation often requires flexibility around a traditional '9-5' but then so do most roles in the technology sector.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Open communication
- Clear company direction and vision
- Building a company
- Impact and influence as an employeer
cons: Don't come and join this company if you do not believe in cloud

headline: Transformational With Great Prospects
pros: The company has a transformational product set that sits right where our industry is heading, so they are ahead of the curve. This is where all the most successful companies start. They are winning big accounts and seem to have a genuine prospect of having a successful IPO.
cons: In Europe Zscaler is still operating out of serviced offices, it still feels like a start up in many ways. That said, everything you would expect to happen is happening to allow the company to grow.

headline: The most exciting company I've ever worked for....truly transformational
pros: Zscaler is one of the few organisations where as a sales person you have the enviable mix of market leading technology backed by third party industry analysts, a portfolio of Fortune 500 companies already committed to the solution and a highly committed team of executives and individuals who love what they do each day.  The opportunity you have as a sales person to take a truly transformational solution to CXO's that want to hear from you is rare.  You map this with the skills and contacts you've developed over the years and you have every opportunity to achieve your professional and personal goals.
cons: This is a high pace environment where creativity, grit and an attitude of getting things done will see you succeed.  The opportunity awaits you....

headline: Sales Operations Manager
pros: Very dynamic environment where ideas are transformed into real tools, processes and capabilities.  Employess have a strong voice in transforming their function and roles in this fast paced and quickly growing company.  The leadership has exceptional market vision and is accessible to all employees.  The management is building a "can do" culture where everyone is committed to continious and never ending improvement on all fronts.  This is a company where everyone matters, and everyone ig given an opportunity to make a difference.  If you want a voice, you want to be part of creating a company that continualy evolves, grows and strives to do better, then you would probably do very well at this company.
cons: Like all winning teams, if you join Zscaler, you will need to work hard, be committed to Delighting our customers, and be willing to go the extra mile to win.  Have been here 6 months.  The work is challenging and engaging.  I have learned more in the last six moths than I did in the last few years at my previous employer.  The commit is high, and thats what it will take to be in the game vs watching what is happening from the side lines.

headline: Vice President
pros: Tremendous alignment top-down and across the company around vision, mission, goals and values! Management team, starting with the CEO, leads from the front and by example!
cons: Business and company is growing and moving at a rapid pace....this is not for the feint of heart.  Will be one of the toughest, yet most rewarding jobs you have had in your career.  Does not settle in hiring process...come with your A game!

headline: Zscaler - Innovation, Passion and Opportunity
pros: Zscaler's management cares about employees from the top down. Jay makes it a point to know each employee and everyone matters to him, regardless of pay grade or title.  He is a true visionary, and his commitment to his employees, customers, and partners inspires me.  The entire executive management team is collaborative and inclusive. The doors are open to all to provide critical opinions and have a voice.  People are respected, treated fairly, and given an opportunity to grow skills and contribute to broader areas and expand personal and career potential.
cons: If you are accustomed to a more narrowly defined role, then you will have difficulty at Zscaler since a level of flexibility is required to fill-in gaps with growth until new positions are hired.

headline: Solid Company - strong leadership
pros: Great People, incredible technology, disruptive to security industry.  There is a solid culture that continues to mature and remain positive.
cons: Fast paced, high expectations, typical challenges of a hyper-growth company.  No company is perfect in terms of the exec team or the processes, but Zscaler continues to get better.

headline: Awesome company to work with...!!!!
pros:
* Good salary structure
* Un-beatable product to work with.
* constant learning & earning
* Hardworking staff with tremendous skills & always willing to help others attitude.
* Best in industry admin facilities
* Active RnR's & much more,i can't summarize.
cons: Sometimes shift timing gives you little pain,but believe me it can be sorted out with ease though.

headline: Impatient to get to IPO
pros: Work from home contract status
cons: Management are caring, understanding nineties types

headline: A Work in Progress
pros: Well meaning executive team that strives for World Class
cons: Tough sell with limited resources.

headline: Overall okay, but not for mktg or comms
pros:
-Technology is great, probably the best in that space
-Jay truly cares about taking this company IPO
-Some of the best colleagues I have ever met
-New office is a great upgrade from the original office (location could still be better though)
- Most departments are run well and are well represented with senior management, that cannot be said for mktg and comms though
-Free lunch every Thursday
cons:
-Culture is lacking. HR is trying to fix it, but with how the company is run morale and culture are very low
-IPO is no longer discussed, and with the CFO leaving there doesn't seem to be a road map
-Mktg/comms: If you are thinking of working at Zscaler in either of these teams, run. Each CMO has about a 2 year stint and is then replaced, and this has been consistent for the past several years. Current CMO micromanages people to make them feel inferior and like they are entry level employees, rather than individuals that are seasoned in this industry. CMO is more interested in keeping tabs on when you are coming/leaving/taking lunch/ working remote than your quality work and what you are getting accomplished. The current CMO has created an environment where it is impossible to please him, and the company has lost a lot of great talent because of him.
-Office is an upgrade from previous location, but it is basically still in Alviso. Not much around it, and is not in the right location. If you want to be in Silicon Valley, but in the heart of the Valley
-Compensation and benefits are not competitive in the industry, getting a raise is very difficult. No matching 401K, no paid maternity leave, health insurance is okay. No "perks" in the office except for free snacks and drinks, which are rationed so they don't have to buy as many.

headline: Good team, technology to work and learn
pros:
- Almost all the teams are very friendly to reach out to and share knowledge.
- Very good cloud technology anyone would like to work with.
cons:
- No complete transparent/Open communication with Management.
- No clear KRAs/MBO

headline: Zscaler Overall
pros: I've been with Zscaler for 6 months.  I have never been part of a company that is so passionate about what they do, the people, the clients and the growth.  The culture of Zscaler is one of the best I've been a part of.  The executive leaders truly take an interest in the employees and their development.  Everyone is very helpful and a pleasure to work with.  I feel excited everyday to get up and go to work!!  Isn't that the feeling we all want when we are doing our jobs!  Great place to work. Great technology and so much opportunity and growth in the industry!

headline: "Lucky to work, Fortunate to be a part of it, Great work exposure...."
pros:
- Great Work culture
- Very transparent communication between the management
- Fun filled place where you can test your capabilities
- Trust in employees
- You get appreciated for the job well done.
cons: One of the finest place to work I ever came across in my career…Really cant think of any as of now :)

headline: awesome technology - poor strategy
pros:
- innovative and market leading cloud technology
- global reach
- good OTI (but high targets)
- impressive large customers
cons:
- arrogant
- lots of IPO hoppers in compony - no real team spirit
- micro management
- poor integration of new hires
- "do it myself"-strategy rather than "train the trainer"-principle
- lots of people leaving, high fluctuation
- no CFO for long time, no longtime CMO - as CEO thinks he knows best what to do

headline: RSM
pros: clear goals and objectives with full company wide support
cons: not as much value placed on tenure of RSMs during employment as there was during panel process

headline: Approach with Caution - Inside Sales
pros: The product is fantastic. Web Proxy (SSL,DLP,ABA,NGFW) all in the cloud. The product when positioned right will simply take over the market. It was very easy to sell against competitors in the space as so many organizations are leaning towards SaaS solutions. The people they hire are top notch professionals with great experience.
cons: This organization lacks real sales leadership. It starts with the top rolls down the hills to all the sales reps. We all realize that no sales organization is perfect, but this was probably the worst environments. We were treated as step-children, never fully be adopted as a long-term strategy of the company. Zscaler will say all the right things, but their actions never aligned with their words.

headline: Good Place to learn about public cloud technology
pros: Very talented set of people, Good technology
cons: There can be no initiative/decision taken from Bangalore Office

headline: I have never been more excited about a company!
pros:
Bleeding edge technology
Disruptive & Transformational
Working with the brightest in the industry
Security is #2 most important area for IT execs to move to the cloud.
cons: Our cadence is swift - If you are ready to challenge yourself and do the best work of your career while building something special - contact Zscaler. If complacency is what you are looking for, this isn't the company for you.

headline: Zscaler Great, Experience not so much...
pros: Zscaler is a great company poised to do very well in the market.   They have competitive salaries, and a great outlook on the future.
cons: The leadership can be very overwhelming.  There is a lot of micromanaging and there is no area for you to actually provide positive or negative input and have it be taken seriously.

headline: Not a great place for sales and marketing
pros: Great technology with large, well-known Global 2000 customers, industry recognition and market traction.
cons:
Where do I begin?

For anyone in the sales and marketing orgs, beware that there is high turnover with the CMO and CRO roles turning over every 2 years or less with their high-performing staff soon following (and leaving the employees who can't get jobs elsewhere).  Even the CFO has left recently putting into question the IPO timeline they have been continually touting.  

Even with a great technology, the company gets in its own way in terms of executing well to capture market demand.  The company started a team to go after the mid-market, for example, and it should have been a market they could have won but recently they dismissed the whole sales team and it's clear they will re-group and only serve the large enterprise.

Finally, Jay is an accomplished serial entrepreneur but is a micromanager.  It might have worked with a smaller engineering organization but it doesn't scale to 200+ sales and marketing employees globally.  As a proof point, EMEA tends to do better than North America because those teams are more free to execute!

headline: Sales
pros: Great Product. They do somehow lure in top talent from around the industry with fake promises, including an IPO that is never going to happen, especially with the recent departure of the CFO. CEO is very good at "playing the games", a la Gartner Magic Quadrant and somehow gaining Unicorn Status.
cons:
CEO is a control freak and as cheap as they come who uses his credit card to book travel through Expedia for the company so he can get the points. 
Mass exodus of employees over the past month including the CFO and 4 CMO's in the past few years.

headline: I have joind this Organization a mnth back and so for everyone is supporting me helpng me.Comunication is so Transparent
pros:
1: Communication is so Transparent.
2:Get a chance to attend meetings with Global VP's.
3:Higher management has high caliber and vision to achieve what is targeted.
4:Takes care of employees great leave policy ,Insurance policy,Transportation.
5:Excellent team mates,u can set ur own goal management helps u to achieve it.
cons:
In pantry too much of snacks ,We should focous bringing more healthy things like sprouts,Fruit juices,Fruits.

If we could bring in some Indoor sports like TT and snooker that will help us maintain work life balance.

headline: Happy at Zsclaer
pros:
I'd say Zscaler is a 4+ star company with solid potential to be a 5 star company.  

It's a late stage pre-ipo company with the typical pros and cons that go along with that.  If you like that type of environment you'll love it here.  Know that it's not a like a Google or Facebook that spend enormous amounts of money on free everything everywhere. But it's also not an uncaring environment that takes advantage of its employees.  I'd say its a good balance that is run smartly.

Yes there is free food, snacks and drinks.  They bring in lunch for everyone on Thursdays and celebrate milestones with happy hour type celebrations. But that's not what makes it 4 stars - What makes it cool is people actually stay and hang out together.  They don't just grab food and go back to their desk. You can see that people are friends and like to spend time with each other. 

The network security market is the place to be and the cloud approach is clearly ahead of the game.  There is no question that in 5 to 10 years' time cloud based security will be the primary approach to network security.  It's a good feeling to be at a company with products that are ahead of the game.
cons:
Again, its the typical late stage pre-ipo stuff like lack of tools or people to get things done as quickly as you'd like.  If you are used to that you know how to deal with it.

Core benefits are competitive but having some of the fringe stuff would push the rating higher - more generous time off policy, lower out of pocket expenses, education reimbursement, etc.  I suspect more will come as the company grows.

headline: Difficult place to work
pros:
The cloud-based product is unique and has a chance to make a significant mark in the security field.
Many wonderful, talented people working here.
cons:
Others have said it before. This is Jay's company and he is not the person to lead it into the future. He has a small group of trusted insiders and many of them are in that circle because of their ability to pull Jay's strings. Many people are frustrated, not only by the lack of what seems to be an IPO that is constantly pushed further and further in to the future but because of the seemingly constant need to navigate the political waters of Zscaler.

Zscaler may still succeed because they've built something unique. However, making money is not the only measure of a company's success. Jay doesn't balance culture with the other aspects of running  a company. Unfortunate.

headline: This a promising company with significant problems on multiple levels
pros:
- Without a doubt, Zscaler's core technology is superior to nearly everyone we're competing against, particularly when you compare the Zscaler Cloud against more traditional appliance-based solutions. If my review were based on the tech alone, it would easily be 4+ stars

- Product Management and Development team is really responsive, both to internal suggestions and to customer feature requests. Numerous significant feature enhancements have grown rapidly from feedback from real customers, which is awesome to see at a company growing this quickly

- Internal communication from product management / product development teams is typically really good - those groups are staffed by really strong engineers who are doing fantastic work on a rapid refresh-cycle

- Product pipeline is very strong, with service enhancements and new SKU's coming at a steady clip, and all in response to actual customer demand 

- Partnerships with resellers like CDW, SHI, etc. are growing rapidly

- New Headquarters building is great, and a significant improvement over the old location
cons:
- The entire Sales organization is imploding, and senior management are apparently unwilling or unable to do anything about it. Quality people are leaving at a steady pace and either being replaced by lower-level talent or (in many cases) not replaced at all

- Overall communications from upper management tends to be awful. Sales org employees *never* know where things stand, and typically have to turn to the rumor mill to get a sense of what's going on. Zscaler has a serious cultural problem with poor internal communications (other than from engineering / PM teams as noted above), leading to seriously poor morale and high staff turnover

- Current Sales Org leadership has adopted a severely antagonistic stance toward their employees, announcing brutal changes that severely reduce the potential earnings of commissioned salespeople, and concluding the announcements with, "...and if you don't like these changes, you know where the door is, please show yourselves out."

- Sales management have repeatedly set sales quotas wildly out of sync with pipeline, resulting in sales teams missing their quarterly quotas by 50, 60, even 70%, with no quota relief. All concerns about quotas are treated as a personal failing of the employee, rather than a systemic failure of management

- Marketing efforts have been highly ineffective. Executive team took nearly a year to hire a new Chief Marketing Officer after the previous person left

- Exiting managers after share the same advice with trusted subordinates: "avoid taking any sort of middle-management role at Zscaler - you will be micromanaged to death from the CEO down, given no room to grow or develop your team, and then pushed out for failing to hit wildly unrealistic goals"

- Stock options are extremely skimpy - if you are granted any stock when you are hired, you'll never see another share however long you stay

- "Benefits package" is painfully bare-bones - if you're hired here, expect significant and recurring out-of-pocket medical expenses, no retirement funds matching whatsoever, etc. I've seen fast food jobs with cushier benefit packages

- HR team is highly ineffective. Expect no support, encouragement or guidance from them

- Many of the "5 star" reviews you'll read here on GlassDoor are specifically requested by Zscaler management, and many of them incorporate specifically-selected language from internal-only training presentations and videos. Zscaler management are very aware of their coveted "Unicorn" status and actively encourage employees to leave glowing reviews. I don't care *who* you work for - if you can't think of a single specific "con" to share about your complex and struggling late-stage startup, your review is worthless

- Look through the history of Zscaler reviews posted here, and you'll notice several which prompted responses from Zscaler executives. Example: note that the criticism that one reviewer shared of the Sales organization was met with assurances by a high-ranking officer that states, "... our VP of North American sales is a superstar and has been at the firm since the beginning of 2014. We are bringing large numbers of great new salespeople into the company - and we expect to keep them for the long haul." In the time since that reply by the executive was posted, the person he was referring to was fired (or was pushed out), the executive who posted that reply was fired (or was pushed out), and numerous other salespeople and middle-managers were fired or quit. Not exactly reassuring

headline: Great product, smart employees, poor compensation package, ethically questionable
pros:
- Innovative product which competitors can only hope to mimic through workarounds and shortcuts. Competitors might match on basic features but not performance, feature richness, ability to scale, or reliability.
- Strongest product management and engineering team I've worked with - forward moving, communicative, with a clear direction.
- The hiring process on the whole works and there are a lot of experienced employees who can execute on the vision.
cons:
- Miserly stock options with no ability to gain more through service/rewards/recognition. If you weren't at Zscaler prior to 2011 you are outside the circle.
- India based support, while technically competent, provides a poor experience. Larger customers are pushed to premium support to offset this while smaller customers complain constantly.
- Executive micro-management breeds contempt and inability to function. Replacement CMO took nearly a year to hire while the pipeline became bone dry. Upper management communicates unreliably and the rumor mill is often weeks or months ahead of any significant announcements.
- Poor compensation package - no 401k matching, cheapest healthcare plan available (expect to significantly pay out of pocket). Stock options don't make up for this disparity.
- IPO has been carrot on a string for too long - start opening up that this isn't happening until late 2017 at the earliest.

headline: Product Support Engineer
pros:
1. Very good working atmosphere ..
2. Knowledgeable and helpful colleagues.
3. Lots of fantastic networking and security stuff to learn.
4. Good hikes/ increments and Bonuses.
5.  Work place is good, they have great food as the office is below a nice Hotel. Snacks, fruits, are available 24/7.
cons:
1. Need to work in shifts, i.e 6am-3pm, 12pm-9pm, 4pm -1am, 9pm-6am
2. Workload could be high sometimes, as with any company.

headline: The worst work experience of my life
pros:
Built early technology innovation and a differentiated vision 
The company happens to be is a good market space
Cloud security is no longer a dream, customers are clearly buying it
cons: Miserable culture, this company is all about technology first, but people are way down the list of priorities.  Rampant turnover for years both initiated by the company and the employee desire to just get out.  Worst startup atmosphere I've ever experienced and most of my peers agreed.  Marketing very short sighted and weak.

headline: Game Changer
pros: Great Technology & very smart people. Lots of innovation and partnerships in the pipeline. Getting a listening ear from a top tier customers is not an issue as everyone wants to understand the approach. Good environment with plenty of collaboration among peers.
cons: Only one thing, way to process driven. Totally get that metrics are the  key to understanding your business rhythm that gets you closer to IPO however that can also get in the way of selling from a time management perspective. A little over the top on these activities. Metrics are not the only indicator.

headline: Best company in the best sector - winning combo
pros:
Great people - top shelf execs and developers
Technology is at the intersect of two of the hottest markets - Cloud/SaaS and Information Security
Mature cloud and product, disrupting a multi-billion dollar market
Competitive salaries and an IPO on the horizon
Great time to join - not a startup anymore but still small enough for every employee to make a difference. This company is going to be around for a long time - it opened up such a gap from competitors that nobody can catch it now.
cons: Nothing really, scraping the bottom of the barrel to think of something - strict travel and expense policy...

headline: TAM
pros:
Lot of visibility
Great leadership
Excellent game changing product!
High energy
Good food
cons:
Not sure when we will go IPO
nothing else i can think of

headline: It's a blast!
pros: Awesome new HQ. I enjoy coming in to work because of who I get to work with. Everyone is smart, down-to-earth, and fun to collaborate with.
cons: internal systems can be better

headline: Current HQ Employee
pros: A company with a cutting edge product, and on an exciting trajectory to be the best in the security market. The new office is a major upgrade from the prior HQ. Much more open, spacious, and possesses the amenities that makes us feel like a company in the silicon valley.
cons: Very few (in any). Internal communication could always be better. Getting people to know who other people are within the company is always essential. Specifically Engineering vs. non-engineering.

headline: Don't believe the hype
pros: An innovative approach to security. There are a few very smart directors and vice presidents that have learned to navigate the minefield of Zscaler politics.
cons: Horrible culture, driven by politics and back-biting. Petulant CEO has no respect for anyone and serves as a huge bottle neck (supreme micro-manager; won't approve projects; won't approve expenses; schedules impromptu meetings at 5:30pm or on Saturdays). Marketing & HR "coax" new employees to write five-star reviews. Don't believe these reviews; working for Zscaler is a miserable experience.

headline: I can't imagine working anywhere else but Zscaler!
pros: Zscaler is the best company I have worked for.  The people are outstanding.  The Management team is the best in the business.  I feel very lucky to work for such a great company.
cons: I can't think of a single thing.

headline: good
pros: good job for fresher to go
cons: bad location of job and opportunities

headline: Okay
pros: Working on some cool things, if you are lucky to be in some select teams
cons: Some new execs hired from big companies are pretty clueless.

headline: This is an up and company unicorn start up company.
pros: Large company as far as start up goes. Has a jump on its competitors
cons: Small company without name recognition.  It also has a lot of competitors and is in a very crowded space. Trying to go up may distract them.

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
- There are lot of skilled people around you.
- You thrive on challenges.
- Cutting edge technologies.
cons: I don't have any cons to mention :(

headline: Support Engineer
pros:
Good place to work
Great people
cons: Hike after a year is less and needs to match market value

headline: Pretty bad!
pros: - Security is very hot commodity right now
cons:
- No mention of growth rate(revenue, bookings) in the past 8 all hands
- "Record quarter" for the past year. What does it mean if no benchmark or baseline has been defined
- No investment in engineering, only in sales and marketing. How can a tech start up not invest in engineering. 
- Complete lack of trust in employees, micro-managed.

headline: Management Sucks
pros:
Company no doubt is good! 
Good product, 
Good vision, 
Good manipulations to let the employees work with them specially in Chandigarh branch. 
Good packages.
cons: Management keep grudges with their employees if they leave the company. Telling management that this is wrong means you and your job is in danger, and if you leave the job with all the required formalities still the Management will suck your blood to the core. This is not a company where an experienced person can work as they do not have growth options, they do not have any positions where they can let their old employees get motivation and bring the zeal back to work with dedication. Working in zscaler is like, being a slave. They do not have proper induction by the HR, no training method, nothing. Still if someones wants to join then they suffer the same on real time basis.

headline: Fun place to work and learn!
pros:
1. Differentiated technology that customer love.
2. Senior management very supportive. 
3.  Great sales leader!
4.  Happy customers.
cons: Good place for people who understand top-down enterprise selling

headline: Exciting place to be...
pros: There is a great vibe and buzz to working at Zscaler. The company is growing rapidly and the cloud technology is on the cusp of wide market adoption, all this creates a can do culture where almost anything seems possible. Its what salesforce.com must have been like 8 odd year's ago, it feels like a special place to be.
cons: With the growth there comes some growing pains. But the pains of a growing company are nothing compared to a company that's contracting, if you've every worked in one you'll know what I mean.

headline: Great Company With Growing Pains
pros: You get to work with some of the best brains in the valley, building and selling an amazing cloud platform that is totally disrupting the security industry. And at the end of the rainbow is a blockbuster IPO coming down the pike. This is definitely a place I would recommend and recruit my friends and colleagues to.
cons: The environment is a bit chaotic at times due to high growth, and sometimes people from bigger, more sedentary companies will struggle with this. The company is located in a well-worn building on the Alviso side of 237, and the place is getting so crowded that its impossible to book a conference room during the middle of the day.

headline: About to have a massive IPO
pros: I've been at Zscaler about four months.  Almost everything is better than expected. Great technology, strong marketing, big partner opportunity, huge growth in sales, smart committed employees.  The company feels like salesforce must have been about 10 years ago - you can just feel the security industry about to flip over to the cloud.
cons: The building is horrible - but the good news is we are moving in October.

headline: Ask for proof!
pros: Good central location.  That's about it.
cons: Nothing this company tells you can be trusted.  They have been saying IPO since 2013.  Look up the Bloomberg article with Ceo on that.  Hiring so many sales people but shrinking territories.  Direct sales are not happening.  Marketing is terrible.  PM team is failrly weak.  Total unfocused path.  These guys bought Gartner and Forrester (and flat out lied at times to them).  Stock options are an illusion.  Look up what CEO has done in the past with his older companies.  Best COO Lane Bess left - why is that if they are going IPO soon?!  And ask about the 'board' .  CEO and his family control most of the shares.  Bess left and has a seat.  So no really oversight.  The CMO worked at a company that got shutdown and he got booted from Google.  Otherwise no security experience there.  CFO claim to fame was raising money in her last company.  Hmmm I wonder what she is being tasked to here?  Ops team and custome support are pretty bad.  They fired so many people - they just 'disappear' like they were in old school Russia!  And titular micro management culture .  Oh and unless you are hot and under 30 don't bother working in marketing.  Consider sales instead.

headline: Who said Path to IPO is easy?
pros:
- Good vision, right space - Some great products in stealth mode yet to come.
- Mindset of being frugal - Spend company money like your own $
- Not a pump/dump story - Mantra that company would only blow trumpet after 10 paid satisfied BIG customers
-Smart qualified folks
-Decent equity - People who complain do not know the full picture about how equity works
with preferred vs non-preferred stocks. I hope they understand how risk reward ratio works in
startups - This is no longer a typical startup, but one who will file S1 in the next 12-16 months.
cons:
-Sometime too frugal when it comes to items like free food, fruits -One can spend some extra money on quality food and better fruits. Have the vending machine stocked with much healthier food is the way to GO
-Better collaboration across different engineering teams

headline: Sales
pros: Good people, great product and the cyber security market is exploding right now so it is a great field to be in.
cons: The new sales management that is in place is putting a lot of administrative requirements in place that take away from the job at hand. Most of the tasks are so managers can look good and they do not really help the people in the field.

headline: Focused Tech Company - Fantastic Growth & Leadership
pros: I recently joined Zscaler to help build out sales and engineering talent plans.  This company is focused, exciting, committed for the long haul and incredibly collaborative.  Exec management is accessible and willing to listen to ideas and adjustments.  The technology appears to have really opened the eyes of big enterprise customers.  We are getting unsolicited attention from some of the top employees in their respective fields.  All in all, a tremendously exciting company in an industry sector of immense importance these days.
cons: We need to be careful not to drop the bar on quality as we attempt to ramp up hiring and build out teams.

headline: The grass IS greener on the other side
pros: There are some great folks here, really smart and hardworking people, not sure what's keeping them here.
cons: If you're in any non-technical department, you're treated as 2nd class citizens. Micro-mgmt occurs throughout the company (trickles down from CEO). High turnover rate. Nepotism. No work-life balance, everyone is on the clock at all times, no bonuses for non-technical employees.

headline: Don't Believe the Overly Positive Reviews
pros:
--good technology and forward-leaning market vision
--doggedness
--support from gartner
cons:
--company is cheap, pays lip service to company culture 
--CEO wrote the book on micro-management
--high turnover in a variety of positions
--very stingy with equity
--At least two thirds of the Zscaler reviews on this site are embellished and part of an orchestrated campaign supported by senior management
--Inability to overcome the central go-to-market model, which is channel centric

headline: Enjoying the job so far
pros:
-Great manager
- Interesting work
-Growing company
-Breakfast on Mondays, Lunch on Thursdays
- Doing work that I can see tangible results
- Long/thorough interview process to get the right employees
cons:
- Office building is awful, but supposed to be moving soon
- No "perks"--gym, cafeteria, Commuter benefits to utilize because of location
- Definitely run things overall on the cheaper side, anyway to save a penny.

headline: Very decent company
pros:
- Smart and ambitious coworkers
- Interesting Projects
- The company has a huge potential
cons: - The building is in a very inconvenient location and remote work isn't allowed (the new location doesn't help much since it's just across the freeway)

headline: Could not have asked for a better job. Love the work and the people.
pros: Awesome team of very smart and committed people who are trying to redefine how security platform/technology should be run in today's time and age. A very well talented team of engineers, product managers, sales, marketing, and UI/UX folks. Great positive work culture.
cons: Like any growing company, you could always pay more, provide better benefits. Employees are generally happy here at Zscaler.

headline: Average company
pros: Cloud security is the differentiator
cons:
1. Single owner company; tight-fisted
2. No processes in place
3. Significant nepotism

headline: Core Product Based Company
pros: One of the best product in Security Industry , great leadership team who always stand by Employees. Someone who is looking to do Hand's on Job this is highly recommended place
cons: I couldn't recollect any cons about Zscaler.

headline: Game changing solution
pros:
The element everyone talks about in ZScaler is how the solution is a game changer.  Sure, it works which is what you'd expect, but more than that it represents a solution at the perfect time in the market as this is exactly what customers want.

Customers are buying in a big way and the channel / alliances team have recently been hit by a wave of organisations telling us this is exactly what they want.  This means we anticipate huge growth on top of already big, existing growth numbers.

The existing customer base is blue chip which means we extremely strong case studies already to present to customers needing this type of tech.  On top of these, 'real' competitors do not really exist as their cloud-based solutions are nowhere near as evolved at ours.  We anticipate having 'real' competitors in 3 years time but at the moment, we have first mover advantage in a market that has an urgent, pressing need for the only genuine cloud-based solution within our space.

Our CEO is also significant because he has done this already.  His last four startups were in the security space and every one was successful which shows as we are profitable, have almost no external investment and are tremendously successful.

Just wish I'd thought of it first!
cons: We are at an early stage of development.  We are not a start up but have not been established long which means we need more people (sales etc...) to cover the market where there is a significant need for our solution.

headline: Great technology squandered.
pros: The technology is excellent. The platform continues to grow in sophistication, functionality and stability. If an organisation is embracing the cloud, they need to consider Zscaler when choosing a Secure Web Gateway.
cons: Attitude towards employees is awful. The company penny-pinches at every opportunity, pays below market rate and treats all non-technical staff as an unwelcome expense. The lack of spending across the board has stifled the growth of the company. 7 odd years after the company started, the vast majority of prospects have still never heard of Zscaler. Marketing department is the least effective I've ever encountered in a US tech company but that is probably because it hasn't had the funds or the direction to work properly. CEO micro-manages to a level you just cannot comprehend.

headline: The energy here is infectious!
pros:
You get to introduce new ideas and have them implemented fairly quickly
Employees have a positive attitude, you can tell people love their job
Business is growing fast and huge investment in the talent
We are transforming the security space - lots of innovation
cons:
Challenge to do a lot with little resources - growing pains
We need to automate more processes

headline: Revolutionary technology and a great team
pros:
-Technology is truly revolutionary and consistently leading against the competition
-High growth team gives us a chance to put in extra effort and help shape processes policies etc
-Management team is very seasoned at all levels and truly care about the employees and their careers 
-Great place to be for motivated hard working professionals
-Very good compensation package including stock options
cons: -Nothing of significance yet. Just some small things here and there aren't well defined yet as there is rapid growth. I personally don't see this as a Con, but rather an opportunity for us to improve these challenges as we grow

headline: Great Place To Work!
pros: Great place to work!  The people, technology and our customers all come together for an amazing experience.  It's great to work for a company that is focused on building next generation security technology as well as the customer experience.
cons: There are a few remaining processes being built due to our extremely high growth rate.

headline: Good Place of Employment
pros: Good room for career growth
cons: Crappy building, crappy neighborhood,

headline: Zscaler
pros: Fast pace high tech environment with compelling technology. Truly game changing IP and approach to security.
cons: Slight growing pains of a start up.

headline: A Team of Experienced Industry Professionals and WInners
pros: From my time so far here at Zscaler I see the company making investment in top talent from the industry. I see the people here as very experienced, talented and serious about being disruptive in the industry and being apart of something special.
cons: I really dont have any as of today. I'm energized to work everyday and admittedly been waking up in the middle of the night with ideas and excitement.

headline: Hands-On Management Team!
pros: The entire team is all very friendly/welcoming and at your disposal if you have any questions. Zscaler always puts their employees first by doing after-work activities and valuing all their efforts. Zscaler encourages us to to think positive on a daily basis and enjoy our workflow with the team by always checking-in with one another.
cons: Needs to move into a bigger location for our rapid growth we are having.

headline: Great Place to work at!
pros: Many opportunities here for growth, very positive staff and company is going in the right direction. Great benefits and effective immediately on day of hire. Very flexible with days off and last minute request. Children's holiday party and lots of family events. Catered lunch every Thursday, company outings and parties are great!
cons: Building is very old and in Alviso area but improvements can be done.

headline: Amazing culture, leadership and technology
pros: Work with top notch talented people that are passionate about Zscaler and SECaaS. Company is exoeriencing rapid growth on a global scale. Revolutionary internet security solution using the magic of the cloud.
cons: Growing quickly, always challenging to find the right, talented individuals to join the team.

headline: Great company with many talented employees!
pros: I have been working with Zscaler for a little over a year and a half now. Very smart and motivated co-workers to work with.  Fast pace environment, always on my feet... which I love! Nice perks like free Bagels/Donuts Mondays, free Fruit Tuesdays/Fridays and free catered Thursday lunches.  Biweekly happy hours and many holiday celebrations! What more can you ask for?? It’s great to be part of a growing company that works hard and celebrates achievements
cons: Office space not the best place but looking for new one soon in less than a couple months.

headline: Future Looks Bright
pros: Great technology, great people. Rigorous vetting process during hiring ensures that only top notch talent joins the company. Company is growing and continues to increase it's value to the market by adding features and functionality.
cons: Some of the benefits need updating (no 401K match, Health plans are mediocre). Very hands on CEO (this is both pro and con actually)

headline: Great technology, team and leadership
pros:
- I enjoy working with ppl in my team. Smart & friendly...have a good time at work and so much to learn from them.
- Its a game changer in the security field and the product is cutting edge. Scales, is software based, easy to deploy. Team believes in the product and we have some of the top brand names using Zscaler today for their Internet security.
- Open door policy. You can walk up to the CEO or any exec anytime and discuss. They sit where the rest of us are and not in a closed door office. Execs are very approachable.
- Strong leadership: CEO is a successful entrepreneur and COO CMO are all well known in the industry.
cons:
- Location can be a bit fancier given that we are growing now and a facelift for color scheme/indoor decor can help. Although we are going to be moving from this place early 2015 so hoping both the changes will come through.
- Better health & Vacation benefits

headline: Exciting opportunity in the red hot cloud-based security market
pros: Experienced management team with a track record of successful exits. Smart, passionate people who really believe in the company and the product. Incredible Fortune 1000 customer base - the world's biggest brands rely on Zscaler. Innovative technology that is bringing a completely different approach to enterprise security. Opportunity for career growth as the company grows. You make your own destiny here. Competitive comp and benefits. Expected to be one of the hottest IPOs of 2015!
cons: The office is located in north San Jose and is a bit of a dump. However, we are moving to better digs soon. And I'd rather see a company invest in its people and products than in fancy offices.

headline: Amazing place to be among the technologies of future
pros: Very visionary, bright future, almost there to bring great stock value to all the people connected with it.
cons: Almost Nothing comes to mind...

headline: Excellent company to be at!
pros: Been with the company for almost 3 years. This is the best place to be in the high-tech environment. Having worked in the Silicon Valley for the past 24 years, I have experienced various companies large and small, and trust me, there are only a few like Zscaler – in terms of the opportunity it has to offer and the work environment. The technology is cutting edge and way ahead of the competition. A very open and friendly culture is what appeals to me the most. Even though the company is over 350 employees, access to the execs is easy and friendly.
cons: Execution is challenging at times but we have made great improvements! It will only get better, I know!

headline: Exceptional Team & Company
pros: While only at the company for a short time, I have loved the sense of "team" and the support given.  There is a combined sense of direction of focus which is a welcome change from other SW companies I have worked at.
cons: It would be hard to comment on the "Cons".  I haven't found many to date.

headline: Positive Outlook
pros: People! When the company says they focus on their employees they mean it. Professional and intelligent people throughout the company. Regular updates provided by management to employees which keeps us involved and focused
cons: As company is still scaling up you do not see many training tools as with bigger companies....but do hear a plan is underway (so HR actually reads the employee survey!!!)

headline: On its way to becoming the "Salesforce" of online security
pros: Innovative technology, dedicated and hard working executive management, and great working environment.
cons: No crazy Google level perks, but good compensation and hot IPO candidate in 2015!

headline: Innovative company with great people to work with.
pros: The employees are passionate about what they're doing.  Everyone is excited about the future and believes in the product. Great corporate culture.  Company events and happy hours are a great way to keep that work-life balance.
cons: The location of the office isn't the best.  It's a small company so you can't fly under the radar. Be prepared to work and make a difference.

headline: Great company for sharp and ambitious people.
pros: While most of the companies are trying to force-fit their old appliance technology for cloud & mobility, Zscaler has developed purpose-built multi-tenant, distributed cloud security. Great place to learn and be a part of a company that is well on its way to dominate security market. Good for sales people who know how to do enterprise level selling.
cons: If you simply want a job, it is not a good fit.

headline: Fabulous - amazing and exciting
pros: We just had a presentation for the whole company from Morgan Stanley about how Zscaler is going to be one of the biggest software IPOs next year.  It's very exciting.  The company has a huge lead from a technology platform and vision perspective and the competition is very weak.
